story:
ABOUT THE KILLER

Halloween night.  1998.  I pressed my ear against the wall and waited until I heard the last bedroom door closed.  I crawled down the stairs, pillowcase full of Halloween candy in hand. I jammed The Exorcist into our VHS player, and hit play.  Two hours later, hiding under my Minnie Mouse blanket, I had never been more certain you could die from fear after watching a movie.  And that was it for me.  I was hooked on that thrill of what horror filmmaking could do.  

Although this video would suggest otherwise, I am not a serial killer...or a baker for that matter.  I’m just a girl who loves to make terrifying and bloody horror films.  That’s why I couldn't let an opportunity to make my Indiegogo video its own horror film.  I could just talk to you about the film I want to make, or I could just show you my ability as a filmmaker, and the feel Vanilla Cake would emulate.  

The older I get, and the more horror films I watch, the one resounding fact that haunts me is that our everyday lives are the true horror.  How well do we really know the people we call our friends or our family.  That’s where the idea for Vanilla Cake was born.

VANILLA CAKE

Vanilla Cake is about the complicated and controlling relationship Alex has with his mother.   Tired of her constant insults and controlling nature Alex is pushed to a breaking point on his 16th birthday.  At the heart of Vanilla Cake - what we don't say is even more powerful than what we do.  The secrets we keep from each other is what crawls in and infests our lives.  And in Alex's case - this is what leads him to see the world for what it is.  A dark and not so innocent place.

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

The money from this campaign will go to the production of this film.  Vanilla Cake has a very distinct 1950's look I want too achieve.  I have so many vivid ideas of the look and tone of the piece.  So production design will take a great deal of funding.  I am also planning on a two-day shoot.  Permits, insurance, and location will take a large amount of the funds we want to raise.  I have an amazing producer, Margaret Ward, who is so knowledgeable on spending money when it comes to filmmaking.  She produced this Indiegogo video and knows how to budget like nobody's business.  So about 90% of the budget will go directly to shooting labor: paying actors, makeup and wardrobe, and the art department.  We want to pull out all the stops too give the affects in this film the love that they deserve!  The rest of the money will go to equipment rental costs, food and travel expenses.    

THE IMPACT

Contributing to the Vanilla Cake campaign would mean everything.   Honestly, without your donations this film will just be an idea in the back of my mind, haunting me.  The hardest part about filmmaking is finding the money to do it.  With your donations you will be apart of making something come to life.  That’s what’s so exciting about filmmaking I think.  It’s the chance to be part of an art form that’s main goal is too make you think about your life in a different way.  That’s what I'm hoping to do through Vanilla Cake, with your help.  

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Anyway you get this campaign out there would be hugely helpful!  Sharing the YouTube link, posting it on social media, watching it until you have nightmares.  Just getting the word out in any way you can, will make such a difference!

Thank you so much! I cant express how much this means too me.  I’ve had this idea forever and watching it come to together is more then I can describe!

story:
Hello! Welcome to our crowdfunding page. Check out our project below and buy a perk to support our cause and our adventure.

The Idea

3 guys driving as far as they can on the largest piece of land on the globe, in search of adventure on the road. It is the mother of all roadtrips, with the idyllic and humble destination that is the Mongolian steppes. And all of this in a car our grandmothers wouldn’t use to go grocery shopping. The Mongol Rally.

The Team

Our names are Joris Aerts, Pieter Bellon and Petro Khaselev. Together we form Team Silly Coincidence , driven by random, inconsiderate impulses to maximize silliness, just to keep things interesting. Besides the adventure on the road, we hope to meet a lot of new people and make new friends, experience different cultures and see the wonders the world has to offer, before inevitably and without a doubt ending up at the finish line in Ulan Ude, wondering how we should go back.

The Mongol Rally

Organised by The Adventurists, the Mongol Rally is not 'a race to the finish line' and it is definitely not a nicely pointed out route or a prearranged sequence of milestones. No, the Mongol Rally is a simple idea: take a car and steer it from London to Mongolia. Taking into account the first rule of the Mongol Rally, your vehicle has to be technically challenged by the task, basically meaning your engine can’t be over a 1000cc. So not a car you want to take off-roading, let alone drive it half way around the globe. The second rule is 'embracing the adventure' or as realists would say: you're on your own. This means there is no route, no pre-determined amount of checkpoints to cross or days to spend in that one beautiful suspension-crushing mountain range or desert. 

The Fundraising

While going on an adventure that covers half of the earth, each team is required to give something back to the world as well. Not only because it is the third rule of the Mongol Rally, but also because it makes sense. Besides experiencing this crazy roadtrip by ourselves, we want to do more with our energy and anticipation for this journey. We will give a donation to ‘CoolEarth’, a chosen charity by The Adventurists, and additionally to that we will sponsor an organisation by our own choosing. We decided to give a helping hand to African Drive, a good cause that also helps people in Benin to get from A to B in challenging conditions. Therefore we will set up as much crowdfunding challenges, postcards, selfies, aftermath-video’s and dinners to entertain our friends and families, so we can raise money for our selected good causes.

->Our initial goal is to raise 600 EUR as a minimum for CoolEarth and 600 EUR as a minimum for African drive. 

->From this point onwards, your donations will increase the likelihood of us ever reaching the finish line substantially, as half of your donation will be donated to our charities. The other half will be invested wisely in reaching our goals by enabling us financially to change a tire, tip the trucker that towed us, refuel the car and rehydrate our bodies.

You might think our 10.000 EUR mark is too much and we don't have nearly enough perks to fulfill this goal. Well, you thought wrong. There are "Secret Perks", enabling you to challenge us even more or get that awesome rewards you've always dreamed of. Make sure to follow us on Facebook and definitely consider buying the 'We'll keep you up to date'-perk to make sure you don't miss out on these 'Secret Perks'.

Feel free to make a donation without buying a perk by clicking 'CONTRIBUTE'

If you won't be buying any perks or be throwing donations our way, you can still support us by spreading the word. Share/Like/Invite/Hashtag/whatever to make our campaign reach as much of our friends and fans as possible.

If you do, by any change, have a cousin in Kazachstan, a niece in Romania or a long lost friend in Iran, be sure to give us their address and warn them we'll be in need of a humble couch(and maybe a shower, a beer, a meal).

The Car

A Seat Ibiza from 1989 with a 903cc engine, that’s the machine we chose to complete our journey and bring us to Mongolia. Being 27 years old, same age or older than the drivers, the car might not seem a good choice for this daunting task. But we have no doubt in our minds, Silly,#NameOfTheCar,  will get us to the end. We will of course help her a bit by pimping her out with off-road warpaint and accessories, not that we actually know what that means.

If you contribute to our adventure, you will not only be raising funds for our good causes you will also support us in trying to reach our goal. In return we will keep you updated on our travels and even bring back some cool swag from along the road. Check out our Perks to give us a challenge, a gentle financial pat on the back or just to be a part of this adventure.
Silly out.

story:
The ShadowRealm: Synopsis 

The ShadowRealm is a 30-minute post apocalyptic steampunk western:

Long ago, a powerful spell tore open the veil between our world and the dream world, allowing Nightmares to cross over into reality.

They have mercilessly preyed upon humanity, driving mankind towards extinction. Only one Hunter still stands in their way… but her hour of reckoning is at hand.


The Premiere

The World Premiere of The ShadowRealm will be held at 7pm, May 18th at Harkins Theater in Tempe Marketplace, Arizona.

This event will include showings of Twisted Chimera's first two short films, "Awakening" and "Undefeated", followed by the first ever showing of "The ShadowRealm".

The Director (Steve Farmer) will be on hand to present all three films, giving a thematic overview of the films and closing out the evening with a Question + Answer session... and there may be a few other surprises!


Tickets 

The only way to purchase your ticket for the ShadowRealm Premiere is by contributing to this campaign!  For $20, you receive:

- A ticket to the World Premiere of the ShadowRealm.

- A CD of the Original Motion Picture Soundtrack for the ShadowRealm, featuring over 20 minutes of all-new music by Kevin MacLeod, composed exclusively for this film.

 

NOTE:  

If you wish to contribute to this campaign but cannot attend the premiere, please let us know so that we do not reserve an empty seat for you.  You will still receive your CD. 


What is the MPAA rating for The ShadowRealm? Can I bring my kids? 

The ShadowRealm is not rated by the MPAA.  The content shown in the premiere, including the short films "Awakening" and "Undefeated", would roughy approximate a PG or PG-13 rating.  

Content include some mild vampire violence and a little sensuality (no nudity however), some non-graphic character deaths by sword (no gunplay), and scenes of children in peril by monsters.  There is no swearing or profanity.

If your children are easily scared or impressionable, we recommend leaving them at home.  If they can handle PG-13 films with some guidance, then by all means bring them along! (Keep in mind that they will need their own tickets.)


Where will the funds go, since the film is already complete? 

The ShadowRealm cost $15,000 USD to produce, which was funded entirely by the Director through the magic of credit cards.

This money was judiciously spent on film permits, props and costumes, an original score, special effects, drone footage, and food + transport for the cast and crew.  Many collaborators on this project worked for free or at greatly discounted rates to make the project possible.

The revenue from your ticket purchase, rather than paying off the Director's credit cards, will go towards funding Twisted Chimera's next film - A futuristic Sci-Fi epic provisionally titled "Empire".  


What happens if this campaign doesn't meet it's goal?  Will the premiere be cancelled?

Nope.  The film is complete, and the theater room is booked.  If we don't meet our target for this campaign, it just means that you won't need to arrive as early in order to get the best seats! 


Can I buy multiple tickets?  What if I just want to contribute more to the film?

Please feel free to purchase as many tickets as you wish, including tickets for your friends and family members!  If you wish to contribute more but do not need extra tickets, that's perfectly ok too.  :-)

Tickets with either be mailed to you, or you can pick them up at the time of the event if desired.

story:
Ashes tells the story of five friends, each struggling in their own way to survive high school and their hectic lives. Each has a secret they are afraid to talk about. Dealing with subjects like, abuse, acceptance, suicide, bullying and death, Ashes leaves nothing to the imagination. 


Every one of us has been touched in some way by bullying, abuse, suicide etc. It's one of those subjects people don't really want to talk about and even fewer people understand. It is our goal to get people talking with this film. We have made the film, now we want to get it into theatres. This money will allow us to have two screenings at the Apollo theater and cover the advertising leading up to the show. Please help us share our story by helping us get this film onto the big screen

story:
Short Summary

LUPE UNDER THE SUN is a first-of-its-kind dramatic film that uses non-actors, real farmworkers living in the heart of California, to tell a moving drama about an aging peach picker who wants to go back to his home in Mexico before he dies. 

My name is RODRIGO REYES. I am a Mexican-American filmmaker and I made this film as an homage to my own grandparents, who worked for decades in the fields to give my family a better life.

Beautifully shot, incredibly authentic and sincere, LUPE captures the simple poetry of immigrant life in a way that has never been seen before. 

Real farmworkers, real stories. 

The Clip

This clip gives you a sense for the lyrical beauty of LUPE. It's not really a trailer, but it gives you a sense the intimacy and downright authenticity of Lupe and his unique universe. 
The Impact

At a time when the rhetoric around immigration is incredibly toxic, we need films like LUPE that celebrate the immigrant experience and allow us to step into the struggle of this community. 

  • Farmworkers like Lupe deserve to have their story told with beauty and dignity.
  • This story pays tribute to the many farmworker unions around the country who have fought for labor rights for those who feed our society. 
  • I have devoted my career to telling stories from the immigrant experience and LUPE is one step further in my path as a filmmaker. 

What We Need & What You Get

My team and I are down to the wire. The film is ready for its World Premiere at a major film festival in the coming months, but we desperately need your help to make it across the finish line!

  • We are asking for 10K to cover sound, color and mastering, all expensive professional processes that will add quality to our film and that are essential to being able to screen the film at festivals or on TV.
  • The perks are unique to the film, including a short story an award-winning Mexican author based on my paternal grandfather's life, a conversation with me (the director), signed stills from a scene of your choice, and tickets to our World Premiere! 
  • If we do not reach our full goal, we will prioritize sound design above everything else because I want audiences to feel that they are walking with us in the fields and streets of Lupe's universe. 
The TEAM

RODRIGO REYES / Rodrigo is an award-winning, Mexican-American filmmaker whose work has screened in nearly 50 film festivals around the world, including LA Film Festival, Guadalajara International Film Festival and Documentary Fortnight at New York's MoMA, garnering rave reviews in the New York Times, Variety and other press. Named one of the 25 New Faces of Independent Film by Filmmaker Magazine, he is an alumni of Tribeca Film Institute, Sundance Institute, California Humanities Council, NALIP, Film Independent and IFP Narrative and Documentary Labs. 

SU KIM - PRODUCER / Su is a Korean-American producer who is 2014 Sundance Women's Inititative Fellow. Her work has been supported by ITVS Open Call, Sundance Institute, California Humanities Council, Tribeca Film Institute, and several other organizations, screening in festivals around the world, including Sundance and LA Film Festival, as well as screening on several PBS channels. 

JUSTIN CHIN / is a Canon Filmmaker Award Winner with a keen eye for beautiful imagery. His work spans documentaries and narratives and has screened in festivals across the world. LUPE is his second collaboration with director Rodrigo Reyes after the award-winning documentary PURGATORIO. 

SUPPORTED BY

                  

                                                            


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, no sweat! Please help us by spreading word on social media to your friends and peers.  We are a community and every bit of support is welcomed!

 If you can't contribute, no sweat! Please help us by spreading word on social media to your friends and peers.  We are a community and every bit of support is welcomed!

story:
The Journey

Our crew has been following young adventurer Alyssa Azar as she prepares for her third attempt to summit Mount Everest. Since she was 8 years old, Alyssa has been pushing herself to the limit to become the mountaineer and adventurer she is today. In 2014 and 2015, Alyssa faced earthquakes and avalanches which prevented her from achieving her goal but in 2016, she became the youngest Australian ever to finally reach the summit.

But this film is about much more than just Alyssa's expedition, it is a story about defying the odds to follow your dreams, no matter what the cost. 

We are a group of QUT Uni students belonging to Red Panda Productions. It is our dream to make this film to its full potential, and that's where we need your help. Our goal is to help this story reach as many audiences in Australia and overseas as possible, to showcase Alyssa's inspirational journey and inspire people to chase their dreams.                         



Meet the Filmmakers


Producer
Casey Chamberlain

Casey has pushed this production forward with the force of an avalanche. She is behind all the organisation and preparation which has made 'The Ascent' project possible so far. Casey is an aspiring producer with experience in many aspects of all film production and the desire to immerse herself further in the film industry.

Director
Megan Blin

Megan is a one-of-a-kind director as unique as a snowflake. She has overseen every detail since day one in order to take this film to its full potential. She is skilled in camera work and directing, with plenty of experience behind her and a bright future in the industry ahead.

The members of our talented crew are:

Director of Photography
Jake Malpass

Camera Operator
Dermot McNamara

Sound Recordist and Editor
Julian D'Arcy

Editor
Kine Galten

Writer
Lexy Neale

Art Department
Miriama Gossow

Production Assistants
Harry Wise
Hannah Konecny


Budget Breakdown 

Whether we reach our target or not, this film will be completed! All funds raised will go towards our expenses. If we exceed our budget, any leftover funds will go straight back into Red Panda Productions to help produce more films! Our budget is divided into:

  • Stock Footage Licensing - $800
  • Transport and Supplies (crew transport to set/food supplies on set/production supplies) - $300
  • Promotional and Marketing Materials - $100
  • Soundtrack Composition and Sound Design - $100
  • Final Screening (venue hire and catering) - $200

    You can find all the great perks for your contribution on the right panel!

Share!

If you can't donate, don't worry! You can help us by sharing our project!

story:
"Adam and Evelyn Ward are celebrating fifteen years of marriage when Evelyn turns up dead, leaving Adam and their 16-year-old daughter, Mary, emotionally lost. Mary's resentment paired with Adam's desperate need for justification leads them on the search for answers, but as Adam delves deeper into the mystery surrounding his wife's death, he starts to unravel after uncovering her dual-life style of sex, hard drugs, and underground clubs. On this destructive journey they are forced to question what in life is truly worth fighting for, hopefully before it's too late."

About the Filmmaker

Braden Barton is on the verge of graduating from Southern Illinois University with a degree in Cinema and a minor in Communication Studies. Braden has been working on the story of this film for months, and has invested his heart and soul into making a picture of quality for all to see. While Braden's career aspirations focus on cinematography, he too has a passion for writing and directing to evoke emotional responses from viewers. His most recent influences include the work of cinematographers Jeff Cronenweth, Emmanuel Lubezki, and Roger Deakins.  Braden is extremely excited to shoot this ambitious work of his, and understands that any contribution made here goes directly toward his dream of completing this film.

Follow the Money

Our funding goal is $7,500. Where is all of that money going? 

It is imperative that this film has some great actors to convey the intense story of Unconditional, and actors should be paid for the work they do. Approximately 30% of our budget will be devoted strictly to paying talent. 

As our production designer Caitlin Shannon explains, the art and design in this film is crucial to selling the story and this world as a whole. Another 30% of this budget will go directly toward purchasing and creating the distinct look of the film that will build an engulfing world to capture the attention of viewers like you. 

Craft Services are a necessity on any film set, whether it's a big-budgeted blockbuster or a small independent film. Cast and crew need to be well-fed with the long hours they pull on set. 10% of the funds will be diverted solely to feeding our cast and crew on this picture. 

The technical aspects of the film need financial backing as well. For upper-level sound, camera, and lighting equipment, the rest of our budget - 30% - will be set aside for acquiring the many materials that make a film of this scale work to its highest level of quality. 

The filmmakers do understand that these are percentages and not strict numbers, but these percentages are based upon the $7,500 budget that the filmmakers currently have in place. 

Your Impact

With an ambitious film like this, the impact of your contribution will be seen on the screen and by audiences everywhere. Whatever contribution is made - whether it is a monetary donation, a share, or a retweet, will only positively impact our filmmaking team. This project is the culmination of the skills that these artists have acquired over their time in college, and will act as an example of their professionalism as they go out into their respective career paths. These are students that are incredibly experienced in their specific departments, with internships in Los Angeles and dozens of films under their belts. Every contribution made toward the making of this film will be directly reflected on screen as a product of quality. 

The Challenges of the Film

The top two priorities for our crew is to ensure the highest production design value and to secure the best talent available. Furthermore, the timeframe that this crew will have to shoot this film is limited. Shooting a film of this scale in the time available will be a massive test for our crew. On top of that, we are all full-time students at SIU-C. With that being said, we are fully prepared to step up to the plate and confront these challenges. Our crew has been working around the clock throughout pre-production to ensure that we can meet our budgetary goal to engulf the audience into the world we have built for these characters along with creating an efficient shooting schedule to capture the entirety of Braden's riveting story. 

Other Ways To Help "Unconditional" 

If you're not in a position to contribute you can still help out the production by spreading the word through social media, and following us on Facebook (Profile: "Unconditional: A Thesis Film by Braden Barton") and Twitter @UnconThesis. Anything that is donated to this film - be it a dollar, fifty dollars, a retweet or a share, is beyond appreciated by the filmmakers involved.

story:
Short Summary

We are a talented, hard working team of film students from the University of Lincoln. This means we are getting to use all of our amazing filming equipment for free. Money can make the difference in turning this film from a good one into a great one. Our film is set in 1970 and money is needed for props, costumes, set design and actors to make this film as realistic and powerful as possible. We aim to enter this film into as many film competitions as we can and getting the details right could turn this film into a winner! Any money we do not end up using for the film will be donated to the NSPCC, a great charity that ties in with the film's main characters situation.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are aiming to raise £100 to go towards the film itself.
  • Any money raised on top of that will be going to the NSPCC (The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children).
  • Money is needed for props, costumes, actors transport among other things.
  • You will be playing a vital part in a film that is striving for success!
  • You will be helping our team create something we are passionate about.
  • Depending on the amount you donate there are some great perks to be had!

The Impact

This film aims to attain recognition and success at film festivals up and down the country as well as in the online world.

The film has themes on challenging domestic home life, loneliness and chasing your dream. This film may just inspire someone watching to make a positive change in their life.

Our team includes:

  • Thomas Hughes (Producer) – Presenter and Producer on community radio station Siren FM Drivetime shows, winner of Cambridgeshire Young Persons film award. Media Production student at University of Lincoln specialising in Film and Radio.

  • Toby Sims (Director of Photography) - Worked on many fiction and nonfiction Projects, working for companies such as Lincoln Business Improvement Group and NHS to produce informational video’s. Helmed the promotional video’s for the recent Baron Scheme around Lincoln. Accomplished silver arts award achievement for the BFI Academy.

  • Jade Richards (Sound Specialist and Editor) - Media Production student at University of Lincoln specialising in single camera and multi camera productions. Received Distinction  in BTEC Creative Media Production. Keen interest in editing film and specialises in Adobe Premiere Pro.

  • William Michael James Helps (Director) – Worked on various fiction projects. Helped produce films, scripts, plays and music. Worked for Empire Magazine, as an intern for a short period of time. Wrote and self-published a novelette that has since been picked up by a distributor. Keen interest in writing and creating various forms of art. Media Production student at University of Lincoln.
These are passionate hard working individuals with the expertise needed to create a powerful and successful film.

Any money that is not used will be donated towards the NSPCC that does great work improving children's lives all over the UK.

Risks & Challenges

We cannot guarantee that the film will succeed at competitions, but we will be trying our best to give it the chance to.

Film making is sometimes an unpredictable process and things may delay the completion of the film, however with the planning we have in place as well as being in a talented team of four the film is likely to be completed on time.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are looking for someone to do makeup and hairstyling and in return we would give you a credit within the film for doing so.

There are some expensive props that we are looking to borrow to cut back on costs including a telescope and vintage late 60's early 70's style clothing.

If you feel you can help in any way please don't hesitate to contact me by email at 11308709@students.lincoln.ac.uk. Any help is much appreciated!

story:
Short Summary

Hello Everyone! We are Students at Manchester Metropolitan University/School of Art. We are currently developing our third year Graduation film. At the moment the script is still in development. We have decided to focus on the police because there is a wide variety of topics to explore.

We have decided to use the 'Stake Out' which is an American term where police use undercover Surveillance in a location, for arrival of a wanted person or anticipation of a crime. Stake outs usually take place in a member of the public's property, or hidden location, so they can therefore watch undercover.

We want to use two houses which are opposite each other. In the Stake out house there will live a middle aged couple who are kind hearted and friendly to all their neighbours. In the opposite house lives a suspected drug dealer who is linked to a major drug criminal. 

The film will slowly uncover whom the police are surveilling, but will be suspected by the audience?  

What We Need & What You Get

We want to be ambitious with this film. We Firstly need to find a good location, which I have recently found in Victoria Park Manchester. Using these peoples houses will cost us a small fee, for giving up their home for us to use.

Quite a few props will be needed, including police gear and outfits . Professional actors will be expensive, we are hoping to pay main actors £50 each for their time on set. Depending on the location we may need to hire film equipment aswell.
So it would be great if you could help us. In return we will give you many Perks. With every donation, we will give you a copy of the final film. Other Perks available include Private access to film footage, name in Credits and to give your opinion in the edit.
If we don't reach our entire goal funds will mainly go to our actors. 
If we go over our budget, money will be donated to COPS- Care of Police Survivors. http://www.ukcops.org/

The Impact

We want to make this short comedy as entertaining and action packed as possible. Therefore it is important for us to portray the police as positive as possible. Their day to day hard working lives have impact on making our society happier by reducing crime. 

Stake Outs in the UK aren't as popular as in the USA. However an ongoing huge case is the one of Julian Assange, founder of 'Wikileaks'. This has cost the government £14 million for his case and to keep him under surveillance.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't fancy the perks of this film, it would be great if you could get the word out there for us. Use the indiegogo share tools; they're quick and easy.

Thank you for taking your time to read this. Hope you like our idea!

Alice Bywater

story:
A Girl and Her Feature.

First of all, thank you sincerely for taking the time to look at this page.

Second, here's what you need to know.

My name is Elizabeth Lockard and I am trying to raise funds to direct my first feature film. At the moment, I'm not trying to raise funds for the movie  itself. Instead, I'm trying to raise funds to raise funds.

"That sounds ridiculous!" you cry. "I agree!" I chime, so here's the why: getting money for a feature is no walk in the park. Before I even know how much money I will need for the film, I'd like to have the script broken down by a 1st AD so we know how many days this sort of thing would take to shoot, and then have it budgeted by a Line Producer. The more answers you can give potential investors in the pitch, the better. That being said, let me give some answers.

  • What is the film? Co-written by myself and the incredibly talented Maggie Cleary, LEMONS is a buddy comedy about a young woman who has become complacent and taken a back seat in her own life.  Valerie, the main character, needs a little nudge to get back on the right track and figure out what to do when life gives you lemons. However, that nudge ends up being more of a shove when her destiny manifests into a person one day. Through a series of questionable decisions and coincidences, the two girls have to get Valerie following her dreams while at the same time avoiding getting killed by an 80s cartoon-loving, notorious drug lord.
  • Have you even directed before? I have! For the past couple of years I've been focusing my talents elsewhere in film, but I'd like to get back in the saddle, especially since I now have a script that I'm passionate about.
  • Okay, so prove it. No problem! This was the short I directed for the London 48 Hour Film Project. We had to randomly draw a genre out of a hat (we got romance) then had 48 hours to write, shoot, edit, and deliver a film. My team and I were nominated for three awards, two of which we won. Here's the link if you'd like to check it out: Stuffed with Love. This film had a two-day turn around and less than a $300 budget. I'd love to be able to see what I can do with a proper budget, real equipment, and more time.

So Where Would My Money Go?

Short answer? To several things to help the the ball rolling.

Long answer? See below.

  1. A 1st Assistant Director. If you're not a film person, a 1st AD is the person on set who basically tells you when you're shooting what and keeps the whole production on schedule. To know what the schedule is, they have to break down the script--and you guessed it--make a schedule. When a 1st AD breaks down a script, it will tell you things like how many days you shoot, which characters are on what days, how many days each character works on, etc.
  2. A Line Producer. Again, if you're not a film person, a Line Producer is the Head Honcho in charge of the budget. The LP creates the budget, nurtures the budget, and keeps it as their baby. They're the person who tells you if you can afford a location or how much Bob the Greensman is getting paid. They're also the person who slaps you upside the head if you go into over-time.
  3. Investor Packets. One of the best ways to get people to remember you is have a physical, as well as digital handout. Some of this money will go into printing and creating the packets and some will go into distributing it.
  4. Equipment. One of the key items for financing this film will be making a 30-60 second teaser trailer to showcase the feel of the film.

The Impact

"So why should I help support this film?" Let me tell you.

  • The Story in LEMONS is something that nearly everyone, girl or boy, young or old can relate to. Although you may not have had a drug lord trying to hunt you down, most people know the feeling of wanting to follow their dreams even if it's hard. Everyone gets stuck in a ruts, and this story is about pulling yourself up by your bootstraps and getting back out there.
  • Women in Film are far more under represented than men. This is true for both in front of and behind the camera. Supporting this film, even in it's early stages is a chance to get a feature out there with strong female characters, female writers, and a female director.

Risks & Challenges

Are there risks and challenges? Of course there are, but for now, they're limited. Getting people to breakdown and budget the script won't be a problem. In fact, Assistant Director Carly Sturgeon is already attached and ready to break down the script. Shooting a low-budget teaser trailer will be the most complicated, but far from impossible. Getting the actual funds for the film will be the biggest challenge.

That being said, I believe in the script. It's funny, relatable, and has a good message. The best way I can think of to overcome any hurdles that may come my way are to surround myself with a great, experienced team, which I whole-heartedly plan on doing.

I Can't Donate Right Now, Can I Help Some Other Way?

Glad you asked. The answer is a resounding "YES!"

Share this link with other people you think might be capable or interested in giving. Email, tweet, post, or whatever you can! The more views the better.

Thank you!

Through a series of questionable decisions and coincidences, the two girls have to get Valerie following her dreams while at the same time avoiding getting killed by an 80s cartoon-loving, notorious drug lord.

Have you even directed before? I have! For the past couple of years I've been focusing my talents elsewhere in film, but I'd like to get back in the saddle, especially since I now have a script that I'm passionate about.


Okay, so prove it. No problem! This was the short I directed for the London 48 Hour Film Project. We had to randomly draw a genre out of a hat (we got romance) then had 48 hours to write, shoot, edit, and deliver a film. My team and I were nominated for three awards, two of which we won. Here's the link if you'd like to check it out: Stuffed with Love. This film had a two-day turn around and less than a $300 budget. I'd love to be able to see what I can do with a proper budget, real equipment, and more time.
   So Where Would My Money Go? Short answer? To several things to help the the ball rolling.
Long answer? See below.



A 1st Assistant Director. If you're not a film person, a 1st AD is the person on set who basically tells you when you're shooting what and keeps the whole production on schedule. To know what the schedule is, they have to break down the script--and you guessed it--make a schedule. When a 1st AD breaks down a script, it will tell you things like how many days you shoot, which characters are on what days, how many days each character works on, etc.

A Line Producer. Again, if you're not a film person, a Line Producer is the Head Honcho in charge of the budget. The LP creates the budget, nurtures the budget, and keeps it as their baby. They're the person who tells you if you can afford a location or how much Bob the Greensman is getting paid. They're also the person who slaps you upside the head if you go into over-time.

Investor Packets. One of the best ways to get people to remember you is have a physical, as well as digital handout. Some of this money will go into printing and creating the packets and some will go into distributing it.

Equipment. One of the key items for financing this film will be making a 30-60 second teaser trailer to showcase the feel of the film.
   The Impact "So why should I help support this film?" Let me tell you.  
The Story in LEMONS is something that nearly everyone, girl or boy, young or old can relate to. Although you may not have had a drug lord trying to hunt you down, most people know the feeling of wanting to follow their dreams even if it's hard. Everyone gets stuck in a ruts, and this story is about pulling yourself up by your bootstraps and getting back out there. 
Women in Film are far more under represented than men. This is true for both in front of and behind the camera. Supporting this film, even in it's early stages is a chance to get a feature out there with strong female characters, female writers, and a female director.    Risks & Challenges  Are there risks and challenges? Of course there are, but for now, they're limited. Getting people to breakdown and budget the script won't be a problem. In fact, Assistant Director Carly Sturgeon is already attached and ready to break down the script. Shooting a low-budget teaser trailer will be the most complicated, but far from impossible. Getting the actual funds for the film will be the biggest challenge.
That being said, I believe in the script. It's funny, relatable, and has a good message. The best way I can think of to overcome any hurdles that may come my way are to surround myself with a great, experienced team, which I whole-heartedly plan on doing.   I Can't Donate Right Now, Can I Help Some Other Way? Glad you asked. The answer is a resounding "YES!"
Share this link with other people you think might be capable or interested in giving. Email, tweet, post, or whatever you can! The more views the better.

Thank you!

story:
Searching movies to watch is a pain, especially when you want to rent or download films. You come across same set of popular films, or would already need to know a few films to look for.


And you end up searching for hours to decide that one film that you want to watch!


Flickstree solves this one BIG entertainment problem- through it’s unique and world class, movie recommendation engine!


We decided to make Flickstree as a result of our personal pains. Whenever we’d decide to rent or download a movie, we’d spend a good 30-40 minutes just to decide that one movie we’d like to watch. And even then, not necessarily the decided film was as per our liking.

We realized there is no search process through which we could experience awesome movie discoveries. While searching, we’d either come across same set of popular movies through manual genre look-ups, or ask friends, or would already need to know a few movies that we’d want to watch. And there were days when we’d just give up on renting or downloading a film, because we couldn't decide.

Flickstree solves this one BIG entertainment problem!!

It is smart and learns what type of movies a user likes, based on advanced machine learning, and offers suggestions based on them. Superb and awesome, completely personalized movie suggestions!

Add to it, it also specifies if the recommended movie is available to watch on popular websites like Amazon, iTunes, Google Play Movies and more.


The website is ready and now is the time to make a mobile site and an app. You can experience the magic called Flickstree at www.flickstree.com. 

Also, here is a quick Flickstree Demo video...


Key Features of Flickstree

1. Personalized Movie Recommendation - Based on personal likes and movie choices- using extremely advanced machine learning tools. The proprietary technology creates a unique psychographic profile of every user and enables awesome movie suggestions, always.


2.  Critic Recommendations – Recommendation of movies based on critically acclaimed movies worldwide. Works brilliantly for users who want to watch movies with cinematic brilliance.

3.  Custom Movie browsing – While watching in a group of friends or family, users may want to browse movies based on most popular filters of genre, language and release era. Flickstree lists down most popular and best-rated films in descending order, based on these filters selected by the user.

4.  Where to Watch – It is important to complete the loop for users by letting them know all legitimate sources of where to watch a movie. Currently we have mapped 5 popular platforms- iTunes, Google Play movies, Amazon Instant Prime, Eros Now and Big Flix. We will keep adding more sources as we move along, including availability of DVDs online and mapping of the movie to be released on TV.

5.  Create a Watchlist – Users can create a watchlist of movies that interests them. Flickstree notification engine notifies users once a movie is released on any legitimate online platform as mentioned above.


6.  Movie Calendar – This section works brilliantly for users who love watching movies in theatres. To keep a tab of all upcoming movies for next six months in advance, Movie Calendar helps users know what movie is being released soon. It also gives them movies released in last three months, so that if they just missed watching the same in theatres, they can add it to their watchlist and Flickstree would notify them when the movie is available to watch online.


7.  Movie Critic Reviews –Flickstree maps some 1000 movie critics worldwide. For every movie that gets released and reviewed by these critics, Flickstree lists them on the movie page. This helps users understand what notable people worldwide write about a particular movie, before they take a decision to watch the film.


8.  Follow Film Critics – Users can follow their favourite film critics whose movie reviews they can associate with. Whenever such a film critic then posts a review, users get a notification, review summary and a link for the review. They can also browse all reviews written by these film critics, and choose to watch a movie highly rated by them.



9.  Follow Friends – Users can follow their friends to know what their social circle feels about a given movie, which they watch. They can also share reviews and movies on their timeline or on their social media accounts.


What We Need

About $ 20,000 to make a mobile site and an app. And what you get is, an exciting world class app, which will keep you movie forward. Always.

Check out our perks to know how you can help us. Remember, together we are creating this future.


How will we use the funds?

We will bring Flickstree to life across all devices and mediums- mobile website, tablet computers and an app.

We will also use funds to expand into further languages of cinema and improve our technology infrastructure.


Risks & Challenges

What happens if we don't meet the funding goal?

  • It could be difficult, but we would find other sources. We are just too committed to the cause and nothing with deter us from it.
  • Our backend is ready, we need an app and a mobile link to get the process completed. If we have come this far, we will sure travel rest of the journey.


Other Ways You Can Help

Can you please share the word? Maybe your friends would love to hear about us, and contribute.

story:
"Six Bullets" & the Crew

Hello!

I am Isabella Askar, a film student at the University of Miami.  I am enrolled in a motion picture course taught by Professor Fred Silverman. Our class is excited to announce that we will be filming an original thriller written by a fellow student in our class, Joseph Landing. 

Our class is fortunate to have Jorge Martinez, a well established graduate student at the University of Miami, direct "Six Bullets." Led by his vision, it is our goal as a team to produce the best quality film we can make! 

We need YOUR help to create a short film that is worthy of popcorn munching! With the proper funding, our team will be able to reach our fullest potential and put our best foot forward.

What We Need & What You Get

Funding for "Six Bullets" will go to the following categories: location fees, props, wardrobe, filmmaking equipment, graphic and digital design, craft services, and festival fees.

Top donors will have the opportunity to have a private showing before the official release date of the film!

The Impact

You can be a part of a campaign that will foster the spirit and creativity of young and eager filmmakers!

Risks & Challenges

Being a young team, we are faced with the challenge of managing our time properly, but with the leadership provided by several of our crew members as well as from our director and professor, we are certain that we will succeed in our time management endeavors as much as we will progress, with some of us taking our first steps forward in the filmmaking realm.

Other Ways You Can Help

Word of mouth is the best kind of advertising the world can offer! Tell all your friends and movie buffs to check out our campaign over lunch, via text, our social media, and through Indiegogo's sharing tools!

story:
Short Summary

Faabe (pronounced Fab) Cupcakes is one of Chicagoland's premier gourmet cupcake Bakery. Kenya and Quinton Posley started out baking from home in 2012 and within a year business was booming.  In 2013, a new fabulous storefront was constructed in South Holland, IL.  Let me tell you it was not easy keeping up with the bills and the quality.  On December 24, 2015, the FAABE South Holland location closed because we decided to keep the quality and get rid of the massive overhead.   That is when the Roll with FAABE campaign began.  The "Roll with Faabe" campaign is a play on the idea of bringing our Faabe Cupcakes family along for the ride on our new adventure of going mobile. "It takes a village" is Faabe Cupcakes motto and is designed to assist in sponsoring individuals to fulfill and enrich their dreams. Along the way, we've all had help in one way or another. In keeping with the spirit of giving back, we've decided to pay forward that which was given to us. Our campaign means everything and embarks on (3) main ideas. 
1) Assisting in sponsoring (5) individuals with their dreams;
2) Building Small Business Entrepreneurship; and
3) Bringing the  Faabe Cupcakes experience right to your doorstep.
Chicago, like many inner city neighborhoods throughout the country, is in a state of emergency. Our campaign, keeping in the vein of "it takes a village " will be extremely helpful in reintroducing the concept that it will take each and everyone of us to bring this city to some form of stabilization. Our dedication to assisting/sponsoring our "it takes a village" recipients is just the beginning of Faabe Cupcakes long and lasting philanthropy. With your help, we plan to not only crowd fund for our company but encourage and mentor others on how to become effective citizens and stewards of others.

What We Need & What You Get

Faabe is looking to raise $25,000.00 in order to purchase, build-out, and license a Food truck.  We will also donate a percentage of our proceeds to five of FAABE special villagers so that they may pursue their dreams.  

You will help FAABE roll into your neighborhood and deliver its fresh baked goodness.  For your special gift, FAABE will send you a voucher for cupcakes. 

The Impact

Our city, Chicago, has been plagued with unprecedented violence as of late.  In order to curtail the unrest in our city, there needs to be a grassroots awareness and a sense of community restored to our neighborhoods and our city.  Simple acts of kindness such as the sponsorships that FAABE promotes through our generous donors will go a long way.  You are not just helping us realize our dream, you are aiding in the startup of a real Bottoms Up movement to reinvigorate the "it takes a village" mindset.  As successful parents, business owners and faithful individuals, we have built a following of sorts and have brought together people of different backgrounds.  Your contribution will allow FAABE to give back and do what we have always done best and that's bring people together.

Risks & Challenges

We understand that times are hard for everyone, which is why even a $1 would be appreciated.  At the end of this campaign we may only raise a quarter or half of what we need to purchase our Food Truck.  However, we stand strong in faith.  In the case that we do not raise all that we need we are preparing to find trucks in many different price ranges.  We are also seeking labor donations for the build-out and décor of the truck.  No stone will be left unturned.  Having a storefront business has prepared us for the challenges of being business owners.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not contribute monetarily we understand.  However, if you would take the time to share our link, using the Indiegogo share tool, we would truly appreciate you.  Please help us get the word out.  We promise not to disappoint.

story:
We here at Breakway want your support to help build the foundation of this new production company. With your support we can set out to achieve every goal we have created!

  • 1-2 Feature Film each year under $5 million budgets 
  • Distribute ground-breaking and revolutionary content to millions
  • Allow more and more young visionaries to create a new film
And this is just the start!

The Break Down:


The Impact

Your financial support will give us the opportunity to reach and uplift millions with moving stories. And what sets us apart is the opportunity we give the new filmmaker to express their passion and creativity. We want their vision to be seen on a massive scale! 

With your continued support we can dedicate Breakway Pictures to the new generation of filmmakers in the world!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even without your financial support you can share our vision with the world, post it on social media, tell your friends, and encourage others to take a look at our campaign!

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT! 


                                                               Spread the Word!

Visit our website to learn more about our FIRST Feature Film, The Hurt!

story:
The Story

Opposites Retract is a dramedy about friendship and how friendships can deteriorate over time when not taken care of. It’s a story about two friends in their last semester of college deciding to have an official friend breakup, for closure. This happens after an uncomfortable war of words that concludes in them meeting one last time to return each other’s things and say goodbye for good. Soon after, they both feel remorse and regret about how everything happened.

Who we are

Our crew is made entirely of students with a passion for filmmaking. Delta Kappa Alpha is a professional co-ed cinema fraternity that strives to create a collaborative and supportive environment for cinematic artists to network and express themselves creatively. We help develop our members' skills, creativity, and professionalism, and to help us understand what it's like to make a film from start to finish and work in the industry.

Where your donation will be going

Since this is a student production, the entire budget will be earned based on donations and money raised through fundraisers. Our priority is making sure the image looks nice, and that we get a stellar performance, so most of our money is going towards equipment and paying our actors. Our crew is made entirely of students working voluntarily from our organization, so we have budgeted to make sure they are well fed as well as festival submissions and production design.


The Crew

Matias Espinosa - Director

Matias Espinosa is the writer and director of Opposites Retract and a third-year Radio-Television-Film student at UT Austin. He has been screenwriting since he was a teenager, and has recently grown a passion for directing during his time at UT. Matias also loves the acting and casting aspects of filmmaking. Besides film, you might find Matias playing/writing music, going on runs, or sniffing anything lavender-scented. He hopes that Opposites Retract will help him and everyone who is part of it expand their filmmaking skills.

Julian Alvarado - Producer

Julian is a second year Radio Television Film major at the University of Texas at Austin and will be serving as the producer of Opposites Retract. With experience in other Delta Kappa Alpha productions Plus One, Expecting, PB, and The Pyramids, Julian has contributed to a wide variety of jobs but his interests lie in producing and he hopes to explore editing and directing in the future. In addition to this film, he is currently working as the Assistant Director on Silent Night. He is most in his element when he is spending time with his family, friends, and his dog Gizmo. 

Sienna Milanowski - Director of Photography

Sienna is a freshman RTF major at the University of Texas at Austin and an active member of Delta Kappa Alpha Cinema Fraternity. A native of Atlanta, Georgia, Sienna has been surrounded by creative energy from a young age. Growing up heavily involved in art and theatre profoundly influenced her decision to pursue filmmaking, which encapsulates everything she loves. Sienna is especially passionate about visual arts such as cinematography, photography, editing, and design. When she is not doing cool and productive things, Sienna is most likely listening to The National in bed or talking to her dog.

Breanna Cruise - Assistant Director

Breanna is a sophomore Radio-Television-Film major here at The University of Texas at Austin and a diligent member in Delta Kappa Alpha. Originally from Dallas, Texas, Breanna loves writing and watching multiple TV series at once.  This past fall, she worked on another Delta Kappa Alpha set, Plus One, and she starred in DKA's spring production last year, PB. Her interests lie in television and new forms of online media. 


Connor Lewis - Editor

Connor is a sophomore at the University of Texas majoring in Radio-TV-Film and Computer Science. He has had a passion for technology of any kind since a very young age, and has found a unique love in production technology, believing that it is a side of film that few people have any interest in. He currently works at Texas Student Television as the operations director. Whether they're producing a concert or recording an interview, he's probably there. When he isn't working on a production, you will likely see him somewhere on his computer trying to change the world, one line of code at a time.
The rest of the wonderful people making this production!

We are also very excited to announce that Opposites Retract will feature an original song from singer/songwriter Chantil Sky Bounheuangvilay!


Other Ways You Can Help

We greatly appreciate any donation you can provide, but we would also appreciate if you can share this Indiegogo page on Facebook! Also, please like our page on Facebook ( www.facebook.com/OppositesRetract ) to stay updated with our production process as well as future fundraisers and opportunities to get involved!

Matias Espinosa - Director
Matias Espinosa is the writer and director of Opposites Retract and a third-year Radio-Television-Film student at UT Austin. He has been screenwriting since he was a teenager, and has recently grown a passion for directing during his time at UT. Matias also loves the acting and casting aspects of filmmaking. Besides film, you might find Matias playing/writing music, going on runs, or sniffing anything lavender-scented. He hopes that Opposites Retract will help him and everyone who is part of it expand their filmmaking skills.


Julian Alvarado - Producer
Julian is a second year Radio Television Film major at the University of Texas at Austin and will be serving as the producer of Opposites Retract. With experience in other Delta Kappa Alpha productions Plus One, Expecting, PB, and The Pyramids, Julian has contributed to a wide variety of jobs but his interests lie in producing and he hopes to explore editing and directing in the future. In addition to this film, he is currently working as the Assistant Director on Silent Night. He is most in his element when he is spending time with his family, friends, and his dog Gizmo. 


Sienna Milanowski - Director of Photography


Sienna is a freshman RTF major at the University of Texas at
Austin and an active member of Delta Kappa Alpha Cinema Fraternity. A native of
Atlanta, Georgia, Sienna has been surrounded by creative energy from a young
age. Growing up heavily involved in art and theatre profoundly influenced her
decision to pursue filmmaking, which encapsulates everything she loves. Sienna
is especially passionate about visual arts such as cinematography, photography,
editing, and design. When she is not doing cool and productive things, Sienna
is most likely listening to The National
in bed or talking to her dog.



Breanna Cruise - Assistant Director

Breanna is a sophomore Radio-Television-Film major here at The University of Texas at Austin and a diligent member in Delta Kappa Alpha. Originally from Dallas, Texas, Breanna loves writing and watching multiple TV series at once.  This past fall, she worked on another Delta Kappa Alpha set, Plus One, and she starred in DKA's spring production last year, PB. Her interests lie in television and new forms of online media. 






Connor Lewis - Editor


Connor is a sophomore at the University of Texas majoring in Radio-TV-Film and Computer Science. He has had a passion for technology of any kind since a very young age, and has found a unique love in production technology, believing that it is a side of film that few people have any interest in. He currently works at Texas Student Television as the operations director. Whether they're producing a concert or recording an interview, he's probably there. When he isn't working on a production, you will likely see him somewhere on his computer trying to change the world, one line of code at a time.
The rest of the wonderful people making this production!

We are also very excited to announce that Opposites Retract will feature an original song from singer/songwriter Chantil Sky Bounheuangvilay!






    Other Ways You Can Help We greatly appreciate any donation you can provide, but we would also appreciate if you can share this Indiegogo page on Facebook! Also, please like our page on Facebook ( www.facebook.com/OppositesRetract ) to stay updated with our production process as well as future fundraisers and opportunities to get involved!

story:
Rafflesia is the story of Salon, a sweet and sensitive member of a plant-like species called Rafflesians. Along with her only friend, Alex, a human aspiring space captain, Salon is trying to escape her home planet, which is prejudiced against Salon’s kind, and explore the stars. They believe they have found a competent mechanic to operate their ship, but their new crew member’s criminal past threatens their plans.

Rafflesia is a  2D fantasy, sci-fi animated short film, about 12 minutes total in length. After completing the project, we will pursue continuing the story by starting a serialized show, that will be available online for free. Rafflesia explores themes of prejudice, freedom, family, love, and hate. The world of Rafflesia is huge, with established history, culture, mechanics, characters, organizations, and even the Rafflesian language. The world also features an entirely new method of space travel that opens the door for unique stories to be told.

This campaign's perks were designed to help you become more immersed in the world of Rafflesia, and a series of planned updates will allow you to learn even more. It is our sincerest hope that you will be as excited to explore the stars as Salon and Alex are.

Philip Simpson

Philip Simpson is a professional writer, and creator and director of Rafflesia. He has written numerous screenplays which have been produced, including one film festival winner. He is currently nearing completion of the Television, Film, and New Media Production program at SDSU, with a focus on writing, and holds an Associate's Degree in Media Writing. Philip is currently employed as a content writer with BKA Content, producing about 40,000 words each month, and is pursuing a career writing for animated children's television.

Alex Julian

While Alex is not locked in as our animator yet, he is extremely excited to potentially work on Rafflesia. With a B.A. of Science in Media Arts and Animation, Alex would be able to create a professional level of animation, dedicating 100% of his working time to the project. Alex is an artist, animator, and muralist that has been working professionally for more than 15 years. Examples of Alex's work can be seen here: http://fizix1.deviantart.com/gallery/

Aleida Lomeli

Aleida Lomeli is a senior in the Television Film and Media Program at San Diego State University where she studies film. She has also received an Associate’s degree in Electronic Music from San Diego City College. She works in every aspect of film and has a strong passion for sound design, mixing, and recording which was developed at a very early age. As a teenager much of her work was placed in editing while using outlets such as drawing and playing music. She developed a great passion for sound and film after being influenced by an active group of artists and photographers, among them artist, animator, and muralist Alex Julian.

Luke Simpson

Luke Simpson began his relationship with music as a teenager noodling on a guitar after school while waiting to be picked up. He subsequently received a Bachelor of Music in Composition from the University of Redlands in 2006. He spends his time writing a lot of music and sometimes also telling computers what to do.

It is no secret that Rafflesia is an incredibly ambitious project. We are committed to ensuring the quality of animation is at a professional level. We have the opportunity to work with an outstanding, professional animator, who will tackle Rafflesia with 100% of his time.

Nearly the entirety of the funds raised by this campaign are going to contribute to producing this film, compensating the artists and voice talent. A portion of the funds will be used to enter the film in several film festivals.

The entire crew of Rafflesia is grateful that you have taken the time to learn more about this short film. More than anything else, we would like to ask you to share Rafflesia if you find it interesting and would like to see it become a reality.

Thank you!

https://www.facebook.com/RafflesiaFilm/
https://twitter.com/RafflesiaFilm

Music - "Passing of Time" by Krakatoa - Free Music Archive

story:
Hi All,

My name is Angelica, (most people just call me Angie).   I’ve  been developing a web series called CO-ED.  I feel that with so many great shows emerging at this current time, there aren’t many that focus on story lines involving college students.  My undergraduate college years and my now continuing graduate years play a vital role in my explorations of life because during these years I believe that you truly learn who you are and find yourself.  Furthermore, I think that many people out there can definitely self relate to such memorable experiences which is why I created the college web-series CO-ED.

After two years and putting the fine touches on the scripted web series, I'm ready to put this into production, but I need your help doing so.  Filmmaking doesn't happen without passion, dedication, and the calling of many favors.  It also entails asking for support from your community, and you are that community.  The pre-production goals I've reached thus far include completing the scripted full season of CO-ED, securing locations, finalizing audition dates,  and wrangling a professional crew which is half the battle.   The next level is shooting, editing and premiering the web series CO-ED.  This is where I need the gracious support of my community.  Yes, I'm shooting for the stars, and I would appreciate your help getting me to the finish line. 

The Main Idea

If you went to college, you'll understand that it's considered to be one of the greatest adventures in your life. You learn about yourself, you make undoubtable mistakes,  but at most, you wouldn’t change much about the experiences except for the fact that you might want to go back.  Once you hit the real world…well it gets REAL. With that being said,  I want to tell these  stories because college years changes lives.  You fall in love, your heart gets broken,  you loose old friends and gain new ones....or you may even find yourself standing alone when the dust clears. And last but not least, who can't forget being at a different level of broke.

Synopsis: The web series CO-ED  is about 7 college students attending New York City’s leading urban university. We follow their experiences of love, life and friendships, while they maintain trying to keep up their GPA’S.

WHAT’S IN IT FOR YOU…

So at this point you’re probably wondering what you can get out of this.
Aside from a deep appreciation for donating to my project and seeing it come to life,  I've created a variety of perks both digital and physical as a way of showing the highest gratitude for your generosity.  The perks include shout outs on social media, swag items such as T-Shirts (who couldn’t use another T-shirt, right),  as well as, a chance to meet me and the rest of the team (if you’re in the NYC Metro Area).  There's something for everyone!

LAST WORDS…

Thank you for taking the time to look at my camaign.  I hope my story not only moves you to make a donation towards my dream,  but to also inspire you to make strides in making your dreams and aspirations happen as well.

All the Best.

story:
Short Summary

Over the last 20 years, John Shackleton ('Shack') has gone on 44 incredible adventures, travelling to places such as Kosovo, Afghanistan and Georgia, crossing continents, dodging armed guards and delivering much needed food, toys and medical supplies to the innocent victims of poverty, conflict and natural disasters everywhere.

'The Ambulance Man' is a real life road movie following John on his epic trek across to Ukraine planned for May 2016 and splicing footage of his travels with interviews from his friends and family.

The doc will be an offbeat and engrossing celebration of both John and his work.

My name is Irfan Shah. I was the co-writer and co-producer of The First Film, a feature length documentary released in cinemas last year and long-listed for a BAFTA, and since coming across Shack's work, I have become both fascinated and inspired by what he does.

'The Ambulance Man' will be my attempt to capture the essence of what Shack does in a film that can be shown at festivals all around the world and that will hopefully go on to have a further life on TV, DVD and VOD, too.

But more than that - because Shack raises much of the money for his trips by doing everything from chopping and selling wood, to giving talks on his previous adventures - we will also be actively promoting his work, helping out when we can and putting the work of Aid to Eastern Europe on the world stage. This means that contributors to the production will not only be helping create art but will be doing good at the same time.


A Big 'Thank You'

Before we go any further, a massive 'Thank You' to everyone who contributed to our earlier campaign (https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-ambulance-man#/) where we managed to raise an initial £872 towards the pre-production of the film. This money enabled us to cover various things such as a Genustech Matte Box for the camera and ferry tickets to get the crew from Hull to Holland. 
But now we need to get through the two week trip! We need to eat, refuel and help Shack and his co-drivers get back to England. We need to pay for the carnet that will allow us to take our equipment out of the EU and across the border to Ukraine. We need a cheap hotel in Ukraine where we can rest and back up our footage onto drives, and we need a small army of batteries and drives to simply see us through the next stage of our mad adventure. In short, we need £2500.

What We Need & What You Get

We have on the team, some fantastic people, including Kate Siney, who has filmed all across the world for just about everyone from National Geographic to the BBC and has recently directed several episodes of '24 Hours in A&E' for Channel Four, and Rob Taylor who has  filmed everywhere from the Antarctic to the Amazon and who filmed with Bear Grylls in Yorkshire last year. 

So we have the talent. Now we have to raise the budget. 

This tranche of funding will be specifically towards the trip to Ukraine in May (which is why the campaign is running for just two weeks initially.)

We've worked and re-worked the budget and to do it right, and to do it responsibly, we've cut everything down to the bone and still come up with the figure of £14,000.

This will include camera hire, vehicle hire, ferry tickets, plane tickets back for two of the crew (the other two will drive the support vehicle back); food; basic equipment; fuel; hotels (please note, we'll only have the luxury of a hotel once we get to Ukraine!); critically it will include all relevant insurance and legal fees as well as small appearance fees for Shack and his two co-drivers.

We are getting some of the funding from sponsorship of the van and the ambulance itself, but we really need to fill up the pot with money from elsewhere.

If we don't reach our target then we will have to reconsider the equipment we take and see what else can be cut to ensure that our trip goes ahead - but we will be going one way or the other and the funds from the Indiegogo campaign will hopefully allow us to do this without any compromises.

The Impact

I have yet to meet someone who isn't charmed by a one sentence description of the film - 'it tells the story of a mild-mannered 77 year old who drives ambulances into war zones.' I think it's one of those rare stories that will win over most people.

I think it will lead to more projects about Shack and in the process will actually give a fair amount of exposure to his charity (Aid to Eastern Europe) which he keeps alive through sheer pluck and determination.

It will also provide a platform for the stories of the people of Ukraine and will celebrate the lives of many individuals there who have much to tell the world concerning their experiences over the last few years, which have been a time of great upheaval  

I hope that I have the tools to make this work. The last documentary I was involved with (The First Film) was nominated for Best Documentary at the Edinburgh International Film Festival, the Galway Film Fleadh, was an official entry at Gent Film Festival and was long-listed for a BAFTA. I hope that my experience will help me to take on this project.

Although our page looks quite bare right now, we will be adding to it (video, stills etc) so please keep returning here (and to our Facebook page) to watch as the project develops into something special.


Risks & Challenges

We're making a film and making a film is really hard! Anything could go wrong - from things outside our control (natural disasters, illness etc) to things within our control (sloppy budgeting, wasteful use of resources, egos!)

Added to that, we're driving to Ukraine! And Shack himself will be wanting to go places and we don't even know where yet, so anything really could happen.

This obviously means that the risk-list goes on and on - breakdown, injury, bad weather etc. 

But just before you despair, I'd just like to point out why these risks aren't necessarily risks to the project itself - you see, we're making an adventure story. If things go wrong - if we are delayed, if Shack loses his passport, it won't necessarily mean that the film goes wrong. It will just mean that there will be more to show in the film.

I think the crew we have (ie Kate and Rob) have spent their careers in tough environments and so we can offer our expertise, our pre-planning and due diligence as counters to the above risks. 

Another risk is lack of finance - again, we have Plan B's and Plan C's for this. For example - If our budget gets tight, we can perhaps re-imagine how we tell this story and our financial constrictions may actually force us to come up with more imaginative ways of capturing our material.

I think that, as much as anyone can, we have things covered.

Furthermore, we have permissions from the participants, a strong vision for what we want and lots of passion, so I think we have the core things in place to deal with any problems as they arise.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Even if you can't or don't particularly want to donate, you can still get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Like our facebook page www.facebook.com/theambulanceman
  • And you can use the Indiegogo share tools too!

Thank you.
