story:
Support the new film that takes a personal look into CTE and its impact on NFL families.

Is CTE in football real or just a sensationalized media-generated fiction? REQUIEM FOR A RUNNING BACK investigates the tragic post-career reality that faces many retired football players in the most personal way. Through the lens of a daughter's quest to understand her father - former NFL running back and coach, Lew Carpenter - the film weave intimate stories from former NFL players Ray Easterling, Mike Pyle, John Hilton and their families, coach Mike Ditka, doctors Ann McKee, Julian Bailes, and Bennet Omalu, and others, to investigate an exploding public health crisis decades in the making.

Help us bring this film to an outlet near you! We've had a tremendous response from initial screenings and are ready to get the film out to a wider audience, but we need your help!

"Riveting!"

                         -Jeanne Marie Laskas, Author, New York Times bestseller, Concussion

"This is beautiful insanity!"

                                                                   - Dave Birkett, Detroit Free Press, March 31, 2016

"Sensational... Poignant, informative, beautiful-looking. Sweet and (appropriately) brutal."

- Jon Wertheim, Executive Editor, Sports Illustrated

"...Intelligently and empathically examines the paradox of American football for families, spectators and athletes alike."

- David Marannis, New York Review of Books, January 2016



Lew Carpenter was one of the most respected football minds of his era. Not only an NFL World Champion running back for Vince Lombardi’s Green Bay Packers, he also mentored some of football's greatest names during his thirty year NFL coaching career.

When Lew became the 18th NFL player to be diagnosed with CTE (Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy) a degenerative neurocognitive disorder that can cause episodes of rage, social withdrawal, and other unusual behaviors, his family was stunned.
They had believed that Boston University’s brain bank needed Lew's brain as a control subject for a new study on concussions in former NFL players. The truth - that Lew was an advanced case of an allegedly "new" disease - set in motion a four-year investigation into America's favorite spectator sport by Lew's youngest daughter.
 

"A tale that needed to be told"

At the urging of her friend and producer, Sara Dee, they embarked on a road trip to uncover the truth. Carpenter saw a glimmer of hope in this diagnosis: Could a better understanding of this disease help her reframe the depression, obsessiveness, forgetfulness, and unpredictable temper that had so profoundly complicated her relationship with her dad?


"If this was true, why would we still celebrate the game and its players?"

What drove her father and his peers take part in a sport that could ultimately destroy their minds? From Lew Carpenter's hometown in Arkansas, to Green Bay's Lambeau Field, to the assisted living homes housing afflicted retirees, the filmmakers met with players, coaches, families, scientists and historians to understand the complex medical and social history of CTE, including the history of organization that promotes the game.



The resulting film, REQUIEM FOR A RUNNING BACK, interweaves Rebecca Carpenter’s personal story of living with her father’s undiagnosed CTE, her family’s 40-year relationship to the game; and the stories of other families living with the disease including Mike Pyle (Chicago Bears), John Hilton (Pittsburgh Steelers), Ray Easterling (Atlanta Falcons) and Greg Lens (Atlanta Falcons); the personal accounts of former NFL players including Hall of Famers Mike Ditka and James Lofton; along with the pointed testimonies of acclaimed doctors and scientists including, Bennet Omalu, who was the first to identify the disease in former NFL players, neuropathologist Ann McKee, neurosurgeon Julian Bailes, and neuroscientist David Hovda, who have pioneered research in the area of traumatic brain injury.

Recent News

Requiem for a Running Back screened at the Detroit Free Press "Freep" Film Festival on March 31 with two screenings and two panel discussions featuring the filmmakers, ex-NFL players and brain injury specialists.

Here, former NFL player Chris Borland joined the discussion panel after the premiere of "Requiem for a Running Back" at the Detroit Institute of Arts on Friday, April 1, 2016. Borland is best known as the first player to voluntarily leave the NFL over concerns of head trauma.  Photograph by: John Froelich, Special to the Free Press

Photography by John Froelich, Special to the Free Press


How you can help

We require finishing funds to bring the film to the point where it can be released on DVD and on demand. Funds will pay for archival materials, legal fees, and delivering a professional quality output. 

Why?

This is not just Rebecca's story. With the number of former players diagnosed with CTE  increasing every day, stakeholders grapple with their own, often complex, relationship to football need answers. The results of Rebecca's investigation will help people better understand what causes this disease, how it impacts families, and why we continue to love football despite our understanding that 1 in 3 former players will be diagnosed with cognitive or mood disorders after retirement.

About the Filmmakers

This film was lovingly crafted by a group of talented people who urged Rebecca on this journey to tell a story that needed to be told. Here are their stories, in brief:


Rebecca Carpenter

Director Rebecca Carpenter is an artist and teacher whose previous film work has screened at Worldfest, the Texas Filmmakers Showcase, and venues nationwide. She has produced media in various capacities for Fortune 500 companies, nonprofits, internet and broadcast, including A & E Biography where she was an Associate Producer and Production Coordinator. She grew up in Green Bay, Wisconsin, graduated from Harvard University with a BA in Germanic Studies and holds an MFA from the University of Texas at Austin and a Masters in Teaching from the University of Southern California. She lives in Los Angeles, California.

Sara Dee

Producer Sara Dee is a 20-year veteran of the film and television industry.  From her early days working at a boutique literary agency representing screenwriters and novelists, she moved into feature films and television, gaining experience in all aspects of production, from development to post, working with Academy and Emmy Award-winning producers and directors.  Born and raised in Evanston, Illinois, she received a BA in Sociology from the University of Wisconsin, Madison.  She lives in Los Angeles, California.

Eric Wycoff

Cinematographer and Co-Producer Eric Wycoff is a member of the International Cinematographers Guild.  His work encompasses commercials, music videos and feature films. His versatility stems from a solid production background in both camera and lighting departments on a range of projects. His credits include work with directors John Singleton, Malik Sayeed and Hype Williams. Eric was the cinematographer for ESPN Films Emmy nominated "The Announcement," and has also shot campaigns for McDonalds, Cheerios, Ford Motors, Vh-1 and MTV. Eric earned an athletic scholarship to the University of Illinois where he was a two-time letterman, and signed a free agent contract with the Pittsburgh Steelers. He lives in Los Angeles, California.

Elisa Bonora

Elisa's editing career began with DGA-winning commercial director, Joe Pytka. She cut campaigns for Pepsi, Lee Jeans, Nike, Gap, Sony, Levis and others. Her breakthrough in long format editing occurred on Oliver Stone's "Comandante," a feature length documentary about Fidel Castro. Following the success of "Comandante," she collaborated with Oscar winner Pietro Scalia to edit the feature documentary "Ashes and Snow," directed by Canadian artist Gregory Colbert. In 2008, she cut and co-produced "No Subtitles Necessary: Laszlo and Vilmos," which premiered at the Cannes Film Festival and was nominated for an Emmy Award.

Elisa reteamed with Oliver Stone on the documentary "South of the Border," which premiered at the 66th annual Venice Film Festival. In 2012, she was the Additional Editor on Gabriela Cowperthwaite's "Blackfish," a documentary that was shortlisted for the Oscars and received an ACE Eddie nomination. Elisa went on to co-produce and edit the Emmy nominated "Brave Miss World," directed by Cecilia Peck. She was recently nominated for an ACE Eddie Award on James Keach's critically acclaimed documentary "Glen Campbell... I'll Be Me." Elisa is currently cutting "At War With the Dinosaurs," a film intended to raise awareness about the use of alternative energy to meet global energy needs.

Troy Takaki

Troy Takaki is a top film editor who has cut such box office hits as SWEET HOME ALABAMA starring Reese Witherspoon and Patrick Dempsey and HITCH starring Will Smith and Kevin James, both directed by Andy Tennant.

Takaki moved to Los Angeles in 1990 to pursue his filmmaking career after graduating with a degree in cinema from San Francisco State University. Starting in television, he worked on such hit series as “Desperate Housewives,” “Ally McBeal,” “Tales from the Crypt,” and “SeaQuest DSV”. Takaki segued to feature films editing such notable indies as JAWBREAKER starring Rose McGowan and Judy Greer and BECAUSE I SAID SO starring Diane Keaton and Mandy Moore. Over the years he has collaborated with many successful directors including Michael Lehmann, Michael Apted, David Semel and Charles Shyer.

Parker Laramie

Parker Laramie is a versatile editor of commercials, music videos, documentaries and feature films including "Requiem for a Running Back" and Universal's "Unfriended." Parker graduated from the Cinema Studies Institute at the University of Toronto in 2010, and immediately dove into the world of editing in Los Angeles.

Brian H. Kim

Brian H. Kim’s music has been featured in studio blockbusters, indie cult obsessions, and a wide variety of projects in between. His work is inspired by his eclectic background, which spans performing as an award-winning pianist, creating experimental electronic music installations, directing stage and screen musicals, and recording with world-renowned artists.

Brian most recently completed scores for the film “Hello, My Name Is Doris,” starring Sally Field and directed by Michael Showalter; the drama “Grounded,” starring Aaron Paul and Jeff Daniels; and the comedy “G.B.F.,” starring Michael J. Willett and Megan Mullally. He is also currently scoring the hit Disney animated series “Star vs. the Forces of Evil.”

What drove her father and his peers take part in a sport that could ultimately destroy their minds? From Lew Carpenter's hometown in Arkansas, to Green Bay's Lambeau Field, to the assisted living homes housing afflicted retirees, the filmmakers met with players, coaches, families, scientists and historians to understand the complex medical and social history of CTE, including the history of organization that promotes the game. 





The resulting film, REQUIEM FOR A RUNNING BACK, interweaves Rebecca Carpenter’s personal story of living with her father’s undiagnosed CTE, her family’s 40-year relationship to the game; and the stories of other families living with the disease including Mike Pyle (Chicago Bears), John Hilton (Pittsburgh Steelers), Ray Easterling (Atlanta Falcons) and Greg Lens (Atlanta Falcons); the personal accounts of former NFL players including Hall of Famers Mike Ditka and James Lofton; along with the pointed testimonies of acclaimed doctors and scientists including, Bennet Omalu, who was the first to identify the disease in former NFL players, neuropathologist Ann McKee, neurosurgeon Julian Bailes, and neuroscientist David Hovda, who have pioneered research in the area of traumatic brain injury.



Recent News
Requiem for a Running Back screened at the Detroit Free Press "Freep" Film Festival on March 31 with two screenings and two panel discussions featuring the filmmakers, ex-NFL players and brain injury specialists.
Here, former NFL player Chris Borland joined the discussion panel after the premiere of "Requiem for a Running Back" at the Detroit Institute of Arts on Friday, April 1, 2016. Borland is best known as the first player to voluntarily leave the NFL over concerns of head trauma.  Photograph by: John Froelich, Special to the Free PressPhotography by John Froelich, Special to the Free Press
How you can help

We require finishing funds to bring the film to the point where it can be released on DVD and on demand. Funds will pay for archival materials, legal fees, and delivering a professional quality output. 

Why?
This is not just Rebecca's story. With the number of former players diagnosed with CTE  increasing every day, stakeholders grapple with their own, often complex, relationship to football need answers. The results of Rebecca's investigation will help people better understand what causes this disease, how it impacts families, and why we continue to love football despite our understanding that 1 in 3 former players will be diagnosed with cognitive or mood disorders after retirement.

About the Filmmakers
This film was lovingly crafted by a group of talented people who urged Rebecca on this journey to tell a story that needed to be told. Here are their stories, in brief:








Rebecca Carpenter
Director Rebecca Carpenter is an artist and teacher whose previous film work has screened at Worldfest, the Texas Filmmakers Showcase, and venues nationwide. She has produced media in various capacities for Fortune 500 companies, nonprofits, internet and broadcast, including A & E Biography where she was an Associate Producer and Production Coordinator. She grew up in Green Bay, Wisconsin, graduated from Harvard University with a BA in Germanic Studies and holds an MFA from the University of Texas at Austin and a Masters in Teaching from the University of Southern California. She lives in Los Angeles, California.



Sara Dee
Producer Sara Dee is a 20-year veteran of the film and television industry.  From her early days working at a boutique literary agency representing screenwriters and novelists, she moved into feature films and television, gaining experience in all aspects of production, from development to post, working with Academy and Emmy Award-winning producers and directors.  Born and raised in Evanston, Illinois, she received a BA in Sociology from the University of Wisconsin, Madison.  She lives in Los Angeles, California.



Eric Wycoff
Cinematographer and Co-Producer Eric Wycoff is a member of the International Cinematographers Guild.  His work encompasses commercials, music videos and feature films. His versatility stems from a solid production background in both camera and lighting departments on a range of projects. His credits include work with directors John Singleton, Malik Sayeed and Hype Williams. Eric was the cinematographer for ESPN Films Emmy nominated "The Announcement," and has also shot campaigns for McDonalds, Cheerios, Ford Motors, Vh-1 and MTV. Eric earned an athletic scholarship to the University of Illinois where he was a two-time letterman, and signed a free agent contract with the Pittsburgh Steelers. He lives in Los Angeles, California.



Elisa Bonora
Elisa's editing career began with DGA-winning commercial director, Joe Pytka. She cut campaigns for Pepsi, Lee Jeans, Nike, Gap, Sony, Levis and others. Her breakthrough in long format editing occurred on Oliver Stone's "Comandante," a feature length documentary about Fidel Castro. Following the success of "Comandante," she collaborated with Oscar winner Pietro Scalia to edit the feature documentary "Ashes and Snow," directed by Canadian artist Gregory Colbert. In 2008, she cut and co-produced "No Subtitles Necessary: Laszlo and Vilmos," which premiered at the Cannes Film Festival and was nominated for an Emmy Award.
Elisa reteamed with Oliver Stone on the documentary "South of the Border," which premiered at the 66th annual Venice Film Festival. In 2012, she was the Additional Editor on Gabriela Cowperthwaite's "Blackfish," a documentary that was shortlisted for the Oscars and received an ACE Eddie nomination. Elisa went on to co-produce and edit the Emmy nominated "Brave Miss World," directed by Cecilia Peck. She was recently nominated for an ACE Eddie Award on James Keach's critically acclaimed documentary "Glen Campbell... I'll Be Me." Elisa is currently cutting "At War With the Dinosaurs," a film intended to raise awareness about the use of alternative energy to meet global energy needs.



Troy Takaki
Troy Takaki is a top film editor who has cut such box office hits as SWEET HOME ALABAMA starring Reese Witherspoon and Patrick Dempsey and HITCH starring Will Smith and Kevin James, both directed by Andy Tennant.
Takaki moved to Los Angeles in 1990 to pursue his filmmaking career after graduating with a degree in cinema from San Francisco State University. Starting in television, he worked on such hit series as “Desperate Housewives,” “Ally McBeal,” “Tales from the Crypt,” and “SeaQuest DSV”. Takaki segued to feature films editing such notable indies as JAWBREAKER starring Rose McGowan and Judy Greer and BECAUSE I SAID SO starring Diane Keaton and Mandy Moore. Over the years he has collaborated with many successful directors including Michael Lehmann, Michael Apted, David Semel and Charles Shyer.



Parker Laramie
Parker Laramie is a versatile editor of commercials, music videos, documentaries and feature films including "Requiem for a Running Back" and Universal's "Unfriended." Parker graduated from the Cinema Studies Institute at the University of Toronto in 2010, and immediately dove into the world of editing in Los Angeles.



Brian H. Kim
Brian H. Kim’s music has been featured in studio blockbusters, indie cult obsessions, and a wide variety of projects in between. His work is inspired by his eclectic background, which spans performing as an award-winning pianist, creating experimental electronic music installations, directing stage and screen musicals, and recording with world-renowned artists.
Brian most recently completed scores for the film “Hello, My Name Is Doris,” starring Sally Field and directed by Michael Showalter; the drama “Grounded,” starring Aaron Paul and Jeff Daniels; and the comedy “G.B.F.,” starring Michael J. Willett and Megan Mullally. He is also currently scoring the hit Disney animated series “Star vs. the Forces of Evil.”

story:
Millions of people are reported missing every day. 

Of that figure, 700 are

innocent children.

The reasons are:

Sexual exploitation

Ransom demands

Human trafficking

Organ trafficking

Enslavement

Check out the Horus video on 

SPANISH


Check out the Horus video on 

FRENCH


Check out the Horus video on 

GERMAN


The Horus Instant Search app and their alarms for people are free.


We need financial resources to become better known with the Horus app in the whole world.


In which countries do dangers lurk?

South America with Brazil, Mexico, Venezuela (and in particular Caracas), Argentina, Uruguay or Colombia are as dangerous as "risk countries" such as South Africa, Russia, Nigeria or Syria, the Yemen and Somalia.

Crisis areas are inevitably a setting for hostage-takers.

Unfortunately, child abductions are also a global issue. Not only as extortion for monetary gain, but also often for cultural and religious differences and parental viewpoints in bi-national marriages. And children are still being sold in human trafficking.


"Trust in the police and authorities is fading!"

These statistics show the result of a survey in Germany on the general level of trust in the judiciary and legal system. In spring 2015, around 29 percent of those questioned replied that they did not really have any trust in the German judiciary or legal system.

"Why don't the police like Horus Instant Search?"

The police want to decide for themselves when someone is officially missing.

However, the public is increasingly using social networks to publish reports of missing people.

Facebook und Twitter

The police warn against mass hysteria.

Time and again, though, we receive letters from the authorities warning us of attempted abductions on the way to or from School.

The police warn against deadening (of feelings).

Horus reports are limited to a specific radius to prevent this.

The police warn that the personal details of a missing person remain saved in the Internet forever.

Paradoxically, the police also use the message platforms to publish missing person's reports.
As 100% of these platforms also operate online, the details posted by the police are actually saved in the Internet forever.

However, the Horus app is a closed system!


The person who raises the alarm decides when to acknowledge the alarm.

Once the alarm has been acknowledged, the missing person's details are no longer visible.

    "Finder's reward for items"

    • Alarms (push-up) in a limited radius for missing persons.
    • Details of the finder's reward.
    • Maximum safety for the pre-defined profiles.
    • It is impossible for the abductor to use the app to his advantage.

    • Being able to decide myself when my loved one can be considered a missing person!


Let us help and download the Free Horus Instant Search app now in the App Store , Google Play Store or www.horus-app.com

story:
Short Summary

This project is our final showcase of what we have learned in college about professional film making. In order to properly accomplish this, we must have funds to feed our cast and crew as well and pay for props and equipment. We have a passion for our work and would love to have the means to create a quality product: that's where we need your help. The average movie budget is over 70 million dollars: our goal is $1,500. This means we are going to get creative! 

Our film is a Romantic Drama. 

Synopsis: 

Kyle has been in love with his best friend, Jen, since they were young. However, he has never had the courage to confess this to her until Jen finds herself a new charlatan boyfriend. Soon, confrontations occur. Can Kyle's love ever reach Jen?

What We Need & What You Get

  • You can donate as much as you feel comfortable with: everything helps!
  • We also are looking for companies that may be willing to give financial or food donations so if you have any connections, let us know!
  • All donors will receive a link to the finished film
  • All donors will be listed in a thank-you credit at the end of the film
  • Donors of $200+ dollars will receive an associate producer credit
  • Donors of $500+ dollars will receive an executive producer credit
(Keep in mind anonymous donors cannot not be listed)

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this page with friends and family!

Give us words of friendly encouragement!

story:
Help Me Share a Film on the Inspiring Life + Legacy of New Orleans' Last Known Tuskegee Airman, Calvin George Moret

My name is Amy Serrano and I am a Writer and Award-Winning filmmaker born in Havana, raised in Miami, and now based in the Greater New Orleans area. In the last 20 years of my life, I've worked on many important films around the world that have contributed to a deeper understanding of urgent social issues and human rights.  I've learned so much from the people I've interviewed and spent time with, the places I've been to that have imprinted themselves within, and the things that I've witnessed that have forever impacted me.

By strategically combining the creative visual arts with advocacy, I've even used these films and experiences to positively impact Foreign Policy.

Since early 2013, I've experienced the grace to be working on the documentary "Airman " a film based on the life of New Orleans' last known Tuskegee Airman, Dr. Calvin George Moret.  Through my time with Dr. Moret, I've gained a deeper, first person understanding of ideas and concepts about Race in America; where we were, where we've recently been, and the places to which we may yet aspire.

About the Film, "Airman"

The first part of documenting this film spanned the last 32 months of  Dr. Moret’s life.

This involved a series of documented, exclusive interviews that took place at his home where we intimately discussed private and public aspects of Dr. Moret’s inspiring life.  During this time, we also obtained exclusive footage from following Dr. Moret on the road as he gave talks on what it meant to be a Tuskegee Airman, their legacy, and present day implications.   During these 32 months, we also attended and documented Dr. Moret at events related to this experience including a groundbreaking event with other surviving Tuskegee Airmen to commemorate the opening of a new exhibit at the now famous Moton Field in Tuskegee, Alabama, the historic site of the Tuskegee Airmen experience.  

      [that is Dr. Moret in the front row, right in the center]

The second part of documenting the film involves interviews that take place after the passing of Dr. Moret and in reflection of the meaning of his life, the role he and the Airmen played in history-making social change, and using Dr. Moret’s extraordinary life as an example of a legacy that survives his time on earth. 

These involve the reflection of others whose lives have intersected the life of Dr. Moret.  In particular, multiple events involve the New Orleans Golden Eagles the local chapter of the Black Pilots of America who--as the film will reveal--represent the modern day professional descendants of the legacy not only of the history making Tuskegee Airmen, they also represent a generation of young, black aviators who embody the spirit of Calvin G. Moret as they “pass on” lessons, stories, and opportunities to youth in their own communities.

In summary, because while he was with us, Dr. Moret felt so strong a call to tell the stories of the Airmen’s experiences, the talks at his home and on the road will serve as a springboard from which to tell a much deeper story.  From Dr. Moret’s point of view and ideals, we will trace the valiant history surrounding an exceptional group of men who risked their lives overseas fighting one war, while returning to battle another unjust one here at home. Their unfortunate struggles in the segregated South predated and were at the forefront of much of the public aspect of the civil rights movement. Their uncompromising valor paved the way to integration during an episode in history that never should have been, yet regrettably was.  But from this past, we will arrive at the present and learn how Dr. Moret’s life and ideals may play a much larger role today.

As in Independent Filmmaker, I need your help to make all of this possible. I need your help to use the great potential that exists within great stories combined with powerful images and ideas to move people to reflect upon and improve our society.  

The Impact

With your help, you become a collaborator in bringing the experiences that forged Dr. Moret's extraordinary life to a greater audience so that through film screenings, interactive community gatherings, and other forms of outreach, education, and engagement, all of us may gain a deeper understanding of who we are, how to better challenge assumptions and overcome obstacles, how we should treat each other, and most importantly, how we may come together and evolve.   Side by side.   Hand in hand.   Together.

What We Need and What You Receive for Collaborating

Up until now, Siren Films has funded the first 3 years  of this project. To continue and finish the film, a small film crew and I will need to travel to complete out of town interviews in locations including Arkansas, California, Alabama and Mississippi.  But the most time sensitive trip involves interviewing Roscoe Draper, the last surviving Flight Instructor from Tuskegee who at 97 lives in Pennsylvania.  After completing these interviews, we will need to digitize and transfer nearly 100 hours of footage from our time with Dr. Moret as well as archival material on loan to us by the Moret family. We need to raise $24,725 to meet our goal.  This figure includes the IndieGoGo platform and credit card fees.

This is how we plan to use the needed funds:

Once we complete these objectives, we can proceed to edit a film trailer. From past experience, with a film trailer in hand to use as a demo, we can secure finishing funds for post-production and distribution via grants, corporate sponsorship, fundraising events, and other donors. 

Our goal is to have the film completed by November 11, 2017 [Veterans Day].

As a thank you for collaborating with us, we've put together many creative and exciting Perks including recognition to you as a Collaborator, experiences including General Admission or VIP tickets to the film's Red Carpet Premiere and/or the Pre-Premiere VIP Party; gifts including copies of the First Edition of the soon to be published book of poems written by Dr. Moret Ode to Life, or copies of Ode to Youth a Limited Edition full color, 8x11 photo book of Dr. Moret's historic flight on a 1941 Stearman PT-17 set to one of his poems.  There are also copies of the film's DVD, autographed collectible film posters, and much more.  Check out the photos below for a Peek!

Risks + Challenges

Though I have successfully brought a number of independent films to fruition, every project is different and the risk and challenge of any compelling story is that if funds are not raised in a timely manner, it will take much longer for that story to be told.  Due to  these challenges, some stories even get put on hold.

I made a promise to Dr. Moret and am deeply committed to telling his story, but with so many elders that play a role in it--and with current events necessitating inspiring and illuminating perspectives--time is of great concern to me.  So time and funding are the greatest challenges and with this the risk of others not being in the same room with us when we finally screen the film :(

This haunts me, but today it also compels me to reach out to you for collaboration. 

This is also a heartfelt invitation for to you to share this campaign with others. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • You can share the link to this campaign with others via a personal email or social media by telling them you support Airman and invite them to support it too!
  • Your company can become a Corporate Sponsor of Airman. We have great, high visibility benefits for organizations wishing to underwrite the film -- just write us and ask for our Corporate Sponsorship Packages!  Contact: info@sirenfilms.us
  • If you are not interested in receiving Perks and simply prefer to make a Tax-Deductible contribution, we are Fiscally Sponsored by the New Orleans Golden Eagles, the local chapter of the Black Pilots of America, a non-profit organization -- Simply make out a check in care of The New Orleans Golden Eagles, then mail it to us at: Siren Films, PO BOX 87, Folsom, LA 70437 and upon receiving it, we shall ask our Fiscal Sponsor to send you a letter confirming your donation for tax purposes!

A Peek at Some of Our Perks

[Personalized Appreciation Badge Shared on Social Media within 48 Hours of Your Donation!]

[General Admission or VIP Tickets to Attend the Red Carpet Film Premiere in New Orleans]

[A copy of the Ode to Life book of poems by Calvin G. Moret]

[Enjoy a Red Carpet Film Premiere Experience]

[Receive a copy of the Ode to Youth glossy, full color, 8x11, hardback photography book set to a poem by Calvin G. Moret + based on his flight in 2013 of a 1941 Stearman PT-17]

[peek inside the book]

[Front Row VIP Seating + Experience]

 

Thank you for considering helping the Airman campaign!

story:
HERE WE GO....

  • My name is Gary Ugarek, You may or may not have heard of me but since 2006 I have made 3 independent films, and have worked as both an extra and a crew member on various other projects, many IMDB does not list.

    My first film started as Deadlands: The Rising... a low budget zombie project shot with a lot of heart, that ended up becoming this sleeper underground indie hit... in 2007, I directed Deadlands 2: Trapped, this film stemmed from my need to correct issues in Deadlands 1. This film gained a following as well due to it's nod to a few different horror films (Return of the Living Dead and Demons), Finally after a 4 year break, I took on a passion project of making an inner city urban tale focusing on the brutality of the Baltimore Drug trade. All in the Game starred many cast members who were part of the Barksdale drug clan from HBO's The Wire, and allowed us to bond and not only talk about the issue at hand but the brutality behind it.
     

So What's Next????

  • Fast Forward... 5 years.... The Dead Will Walk Again...

    For 5 years I hadn't had the drive to make another film... nothing was clicking with me besides the script for my 3rd Deadlands film, which is a very expensive project. having chased funding for so many years the prognosis was bleak, and if I did another project outside of that story I didn't want it to just be your average ho-hum zombie film.

    My Next Zombie Film Project, yet untitled, will center around the events of societies' collapse. When Washington, DC became overrun and the White House evacuated, the President and His Wife became separated from their young daughter. Her and her security detail are on a Journey to the Northeast compound set as the designated go to spot, when James and Sarah run into trouble, both Alive and Dead, 

  • This idea stemmed from surfing YouTube while eating lunch one day and coming across videos of Urban explorers combing through an abandon resort not 20 miles from my home in Pennsylvania. I thought, hmmm, this is an interesting location... why not reach out and see if I could secure it.

    • After that i began thinking how do I make a story that works... my zombie films tend to be very one dimensional, and for the most part leave a lot to be desired, so I came up with the thought as mentioned above... the 1st Daughter is separated from her parents during the evacuation... missing the flights out, her and her SS body guard are on the road and have to survive the two most horrific elements of the new world, zombies and the bastards of society. This led me to think about the Denzel Washington film... Man on Fire

  • If we can raise the funds... you will be helping us bring a zombie story that delves much deeper than some of your low budget indie fare, hopefully with characters you can be invested in and root for to make it through the atrocities they face. 
     
  • I bet you're asking... well what about the title? Well, I haven't decided on a title as of yet, hence the working title "Next Zombie Film Project". I want to come up with something memorable, yet poignant. If a title hasn't be chosen by completion of filming, Maybe we can have a contest to name the film.

 

What We Need (The search for money)

 

  • I sat crunching numbers quickly and I arrived at $30,000. This amount would allow us to at least compensate some key personnel needed, as well as provide the supplies required to make the production come to life.
    • The money would be used for the following:
      • Production insurance
      • Food for Cast & crew
      • Make-Up Supplies
      • Equipment rental (Generators tents, Lighting etc)
      • Compensation for key personnel needed to make the project happen

PERKS

  • Each individual who donates at least $1.00 - $100.00, will get their name in the films ending credits, while this is a common practice for all socially funded film projects, it is something we as indie filmmakers like to do, you helped us so we want to make sure you're recognized as such.
     
  • Each individual who donates $250 - $1000.00 will be credited as Associate producers, these credits appear in the front or end film credits.(Depending on Amount contributed)
     
  • Individuals donating $2,500 - $10,000 will be documented as Executive Producers.

OK, so what if you do not reach your goal?

  • If we do not reach our goal, we use what funds we have generated to begin filming, and restart the campaign to make up the difference. I have used this practice on my 2 previous films (Deadlands 2 and All in the Game), If their is concern the project would never finish, that is not a concern I would have, as when I raised money for All in the Game we asked for$10,000, and only raised $1,700 and completed the film which was released in October 2011.

    I know many other film campaigns promise T-shirts, hats or other trinkets for helping them out. I do not want to promise this because those items end up coming out of the raised funds, and for a project of this nature.... zombie related... make up eats a huge portion of the budget and every penny saved and used towards the production will be seen in the final product. Also, let's be honest, how often are you going to wear a hat or t-shirt about a zombie film. Every contributor is entitled to a DVD copy of the film upon completion.

The Impact

Independent cinema is marred in a lot of red tape, particularly when it come to raising funding. Crowd sourcing, such as indie-go-go gives indie filmmakers the chance to bring original stories to the masses while the studio system continues to give to the film going public the same sequels and comic book re-hash year after year. Your contribution goes further than that, it also gives up and coming artists the chance to expand their exposure. While many indie projects do not received Theatrical distribution, they get exposure through film festival circuits. A Film of this nature would be widely submitted to horror convention based film festivals. In the United States alone over 50+ horror conventions take place coast to coast every year and they are always looking for new and original content to present to their guests.

  • You contribution helps continue the independent cinema scene.
    • It allows new talent to get their first attempt at exposure.
      • One of my extras from Deadlands: The Rising, has a small be re-occurring role on MTV's Scream series.
      • The cast members of my third film were on the highly recognizable and critically acclaimed HBO show, The Wire. (many of these individuals I hope to have return for this project.
  • Your contribution is not wasted money. When I green light a film project I see it through to the end, no matter if we make our goal or not. As noted above, my 2011 Feature All in the Game only received $1,700 in donations out of the requested $10,000.00. We completed the film which saw  a Wide DVD release as well as Redbox release in over 2000 Redbox outlets across the USA, not too mention OnDemand and a limited theatrical release.
     
  • Many indie filmmakers have the dream but have trouble seeing it through, I have the track record of three completed feature length projects, that have garnered a combined 11 awards, as well as theatrical, film festival and DVD distribution in the USA and Japan.

Risks & Challenges

With any project their are risks as well as Challenges... those being the most risky is an uncompleted project. While this has not happened with my productions in the past I do not expect it to be an issue with this project. Some risks can be talent availability, location availability, cost overrun

  • Being part of the world of Indie Cinema it requires to to be creative in how you spend your money, schedule your shoot and meet the overall goal of completing the project. I recruit my talent and never make a promise I cannot keep. I deliver on exposure of the project, I work around their schedules because like you they are donating their time to the project, working for very minimal compensation, mostly gas and hotel money, or as I like to say... "$5.00 and a bag of Cheetos"
     
  • Solving challenges during a film production is a team effort. That is why when presented with a challenge we have to think on our feet and come together to resolve an issue.
    • One example, During the ending of Deadlands 2, when the two male survivors are stuck on the marquee, the main traffic on the road was so heavy it would constantly interrupt filming... it required us to get extremely creative with angles as well as dialog recording in order to complete the sequence, it took us two days to film that sequence due to the traffic issues, but in the end the scene plays as intended with the most effective angles available. Why... because the actors, cameramen, and myself (The Director) sat down and worked it out together. As a team.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand not everyone has extra money to throw around, but maybe you have items we can use...

  • Tent, sleeping bags, camping gear (We are making a make shift survivor community to make it real through production design this would greatly help.
  • Food/Catering - Do you live in the Pocono Mountain region? Cast & crew can get hungry so any donations regarding snacks or drinks are welcome.
  • Share the campaign... do you have a facebook or twitter network of friends? If so share and spread the word
  • Come to the set and help us make the movie (we will always need extras, Production assistants)

Stay Tuned for more updates as we reach our goals...

story:
The Real Page Turner is a true story. It's the story of a woman who has lived one full life and dares to start another.

Hi everyone! I'm Page Cooper Anderson. I am the creator, writer, and the star of this impassioned, often funny, sometimes tragic story of my recent life. 

I was compelled to share my journey because it is a reminder to us all that life is like a mountain, never smooth, nor a straight line to the top, but boy, is it worth the climb and oh, the view from every step we take. I want the audience to say, "If this lady can do that; leave her job, friends, home and all that feels safe and secure, and just follow the road ahead of her, so can I!"

It's one thing to write a story. It is quite another to be supported by those around you, even strangers, so that the story can be told. You are my hero because you are here to make that happen. Gratitude and hugs. Without you, "The Real Page Turner" is just ink and sheets of paper. With you, the world is invited to consider taking the risk that scares them the most. The one they will be remembered for. 

Here's what we need to make it happen:  TOTAL: $73,500

We will be filming in New York City with the most fantastic and experienced crew for 12 full days.

Each day of filming costs roughly 6% of the budget here's where the money goes:

 

Actors and their unions: "Speak the speech, I pray you" WS- Hamlet 

All actors will be paid the SAG ultra low budget day rate.  

Actor fees are 10% of this budget.

Crew: lights, camera, action!  55%

 This is our biggest expense and is a large umbrella of expenses:    It includes camera equipment, lighting equipment, audio recording/mixing, script supervisor, set design, costume design, props, hair and make up, production assistants and labor expenses for each department. 

Post Production:  20% this is for Editing, Color Correcting, Sound mixing,   

Transportation:  5% percent of the budget - We are shooting one day on location in Pennsylvania!  

Insurance: lawsuits be gone! 2% of budget

We are proud to say that we have product insurance handled by Truman Van Dyke Co. 

Locations are 3% of the budget

Locations and transportation: Can I use your house, restaurant, piece of sidewalk, for one day? I have to get 30 people there how?  

We found some authentic York restaurants, hair salons and apartments!

5% of the budget Food: If I feed them well, they will come!

Feeding the cast and crew each day.

What will we do if we don't reach our goal? I have written 12 episodes. If I can only make one episode, then I will make one! I know it will entice people to want more! 

What if something goes wrong? A lot will go wrong! Resilience is part of the equation and problem solving the other. I always say surround yourself with nutritious people that are smarter than you. And I have. With the help of said smarter people, I have assembled a brain trust of talented, brilliant movers and shakers in New York City. I had my Dorothy moment, when each one said yes and signed on. The rest is cake (and I will eat that, too!).

Are you are starving artist? Ready money isn't always so ready. If you press the share button supplied by indiegogo with all your fb friends, just think what you will have done for this project! Many just don't bother. Dare to bother! Take meaningful action. The Wizard will grant you wishes ten fold, he will.

What We Need & What You Get - we have staffed a full crew!

OUR CREW:

Executive Producer: Page Anderson

Director: Clyde Baldo

Producer: Dana Marisa Schoenfeld

Director of Photography Toru Nishiubo

1st AD: Renee Stork

Associate producer: Shannon Hamm

1st AC: Isamu Maeda

2nd AD: John Burnett

Script Supervisor: Lee Ann Hoover

Sound Mixer: Zach Travis

Gaffer: Jonathan Baudoin / Niklas Moller

Grip: Makato Matsuo / Tetsuya Arimori

Editor: Jessica Green

Hair and Make up: Cindi Harrow

Set design: Charlie Robinson

Wardrobe: Jessica Cronin

Production assistants: Alicia Javier / William Roberts Lee

Catering

The Impact

We believe this project will inspire people of all ages all over the world to fight for their dreams and live the life over the rainbow, no matter what stumbling blocks are set in their path. One of our themes is addiction, which, sadly, has little to no representation in the Web Series genre and a topic that cannot be ignored.

Risks & Challenges

There are always risks and challenges when in comes to filming a series but we plan to tackle each one head on. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word!

story:
This film is based on our friend's experience who survived the Aurora Theater Shooting.  The film deals with many volatile social issues, but it doesn't take a side.  With much of the media and film industry polarizing issues, we want to humanize them, and see where we can strive forward, together.  

However - We need help with the marketing costs in order to have a successful film festival run and land a distribution deal.

Our world premiere is already secure, as we've been accepted to the Oaxaca Film Festival in Mexico! It's been called "One of the Top 25 Film Festivals in the World", and is considered the "Sundance South of the Border". We're already getting hit with HUGE costs (The whole film needs to be subtitled in Spanish, World Premiere Press Event costs, Film Networking Event costs, travel costs, and more). That's why we need your help to make our film stand out at Oaxaca, so that we can land a distribution deal, which costs thousands of dollars. And this is only our first festival! If we can land a good distribution deal, you will see American Bystander in the theaters, you'll see the DVD for sale in stores, and eventually it will be available on TV and Netflix!

Once we land a deal, we will pay our cast and crew, and then give 100% of the proceeds to the Colorado Coalition for the Homeless and the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence.  

Please help spread the word about this film and our cause.  If you don't have money to back us, your time would be greatly appreciated!!  Even a simple share from on Facebook Page would be amazing.

story:
Our heroes try to survive over the backdrop of a city at war. While the gangs unite under the drug lord Chang, a cult rises to power slaughtering all who oppose them, Wally West (Kid Flash) and Richard Grayson (Nightwing) try to bring those responsible to justice. Meanwhile, Roy Harper (Red Arrow) hunts a legendary assassin under the employ of Chang, Victor Stone (Cyborg) fights the drug lord in any way he can, and Grant Wilson (Ravager) makes a deadly contract.

Listed below are our current stretch goals; we will add new rewards with each goal passed:

$15,000 - Raven! The moody, telekinetic superhero will fly into TITANS: The Series in a way that has never been done before on screen!

$20,000 - Full Superhero Costumes! We’ll give you the coolest costumes for Nightwing, Kid Flash, Red Arrow, and many more heroes!

$25,000 - We will release a standalone short film featuring Red Arrow (Roy Harper) fighting Killer Croc.

$30,000 - We will shoot on ARRI cameras, the hollywood industry standard for cinematography. 

Below is our minimum budget for $10,000.

We have grown up loving these characters since we were kids. For 5 long years we’ve poured our heart and souls into creating the best live action Teen Titans web series that we possibly could. We really need your help to make this possible. If you can’t donate, please share this campaign to facebook, twitter, reddit, etc. It helps incredibly. Thank you.

Listed below are our current stretch goals; we will add new rewards with each goal passed:
$15,000 - Raven! The moody, telekinetic superhero will fly into TITANS: The Series in a way that has never been done before on screen!
$20,000 - Full Superhero Costumes! We’ll give you the coolest costumes for Nightwing, Kid Flash, Red Arrow, and many more heroes!
$25,000 - We will release a standalone short film featuring Red Arrow (Roy Harper) fighting Killer Croc.
$30,000 - We will shoot on ARRI cameras, the hollywood industry standard for cinematography. 
Below is our minimum budget for $10,000.We have grown up loving these characters since we were kids. For 5 long years we’ve poured our heart and souls into creating the best live action Teen Titans web series that we possibly could. We really need your help to make this possible. If you can’t donate, please share this campaign to facebook, twitter, reddit, etc. It helps incredibly. Thank you.

story:
About this project

 

The Campaign

We made an empathetic and observational film that draws you into the world of two orthodox Jewish twin brothers. It has won awards and accolades at some of the best film festivals in the world. We need your help to bring it HOME to film-going communities to spread the film’s message of humanity and understanding.

“Superb and precise depiction of a hidden and claustrophobic world full of memory and pain, the directors beautifully realize a work of cinematic accomplishment that makes for one of the most expansively human portraits we’ve ever had the privilege to see . It is, simply put, a great film.” Jurors motivation, Main Prize at DocuDays UA, Kiev, Ukraine. 

“A new documentary that makes hoarding as urgent as global warming and as eye-catching as Al Gore's beard. The camera work is careful and deeply human, making Shraga's and Avraham's house a place from which we can't move our eyes. The filmmakers are interested in understanding, not judging.” Steven Zeitchik, The Los Angeles Times.

“My favorite film from the main competition at IDFA” Neil Young, The Hollywood Reporter. 

 “An amazing film following the Maysles Brothers approach. It will be considered a Jewish Gray Gardens.” Jay Rosenblatt, SFJFF.

The discussions that have followed festival screenings have been open, healing and gap-bridging. One viewer in NYC said, "Although the film almost never ventures outdoor, I saw so much of New York in the characters of the film. Some Jewish, some African-Americans, one who only speaks Spanish, all working together, supporting one another in the tight premises of the two-bedroom apartment where the challenging action takes place."

We have self-financed the production and post production of the film but we can't distribute it on our own. With your support we’ll bring THY FATHER’S CHAIR to movie theaters of selected cities in the US; in Italy and Spain, at the beginning of 2017. 

About the film

Abraham and Shraga are Orthodox Jewish aging twins who live a secluded existence in their inherited Brooklyn home. Since the death of their parents, they have stopped throwing away anything, hosting stray cats and accumulating all sorts of stuff. Enraged by the situation, the upstairs tenant threatens to stop paying them rent unless they proceed with a radical cleaning of their apartment. Abraham and Shraga are forced to open their doors to a specialized cleaning company. What ensues seems at first only a traumatic invasion of privacy, with the twins fighting to preserve their memories – but little by little the relationship with the head of the cleaning company begins to deepen. By painfully separating from most of their belongings, Abraham and Shraga might have a chance to recover their lost purity. They are pushed to find new solutions to many unanswered questions: how free are you within the boundaries of your heritage? How do you begin to let go of the past go and live your life in the present? How do you confront the loss of your parents and become responsible for yourself? 

Who is on board?

We feel fortunate that prestigious organizations such as Dok.Incubator and IFP have believed and supported our adventure. Now we would like you to join us and become part of our team. 

What exactly are you going to do with the money? 

Our goal of $13,000 will be used to cover part of the distribution and advertising expenses. Every cent we raise will go towards getting this film out there in a big way so we can continue broadening the discussion. 

  • Theaters bookings 
  • Hire a publicist 
  • Promotional expenses (publicity cost, posters, travel for presentation and Q&As) 
  • Costs of making DCPs of the film

Risks and challenges

Once we meet our goal, there is no doubt that we will get this film into cinemas in various cities. We’re partnering with a first-rate distribution company who will help us get our film seen by audiences we know will love it. We are not able to guarantee the exact list of cities and dates at this time because this depends on factors out of our control, but we do know we’ll be targeting major markets in the US like New York and Los Angeles, and in Europe Italy and Spain.

story:
The Breathing Series is the story of a teenage girl, Emma Thomas, and her journey as she combats the typical teenage angst of fitting in, falling in love, and discovering who she is while hiding a terrible secret. Emma conceals her bruises under a guise of perfection, not wanting anyone to know what awaits her when she arrives home each night. The affluent residents of Weslyn, Connecticut would rather not know what goes on behind closed doors, until they’re forced to see what’s happening right before their eyes. This is a powerful story of love, hope and sacrifice, which has connected with readers all over the world. This captivating series has sold well over a million copies worldwide.

You're Our Reason

When I wrote Reason to Breathe, the first book in The Breathing Series, it presented itself like a movie in my head. I was a spectator to the beautiful and emotional story, recording what I witnessed. So I always knew it was meant for film and that I needed to be a part of that process. This story was too important to me to just sell the rights to a studio.

I also wanted to honor my fans who have made this an international bestselling series by being certain the films stay true to the books. In order to do this, I needed to be a part of something unique, something that hadn’t been done before. I was presented with the idea of breaking the first novel up into three movie length episodes, and I instantly loved the idea!

Last summer, I was introduced to producer/director Frank Lotito (Growing Up Smith). It was exciting to speak with someone who was open-minded and shared the same creative vision for this story. I knew he was the perfect partner to make this vision a reality.

I spent the fall rewriting the three scripts for Reason to Breathe, and Frank proposed that instead of releasing a set of three films for each book, we should guarantee that the audience sees the entire story by making it into a limited television series release made up of nine or ten movie-length episodes and present it to television networks. I automatically agreed, because of course, I want to make certain the entire story is told. This means Frank and I have more work to do.

We'll create a detailed proposal to present to the network executives. We'll convince them that this is a brilliant plan - a plan that will earn us creative control, so Frank and I can continue to oversee the entire project.  Maintaining creative control is immensely important to me. This story needs to be told just right, and I believe I need to be the screenwriter to tell it. I am so fortunate to be partnered with Frank Lotito, someone who is not only a producer who shares my creative vision, but a talented director as well. Together we will create what is called the Director’s Bible, composed of the scripts we’ve already written and the outlines of the remaining episodes. The budget and schedule will be created, and locations will be scouted. The Director’s Bible is the film series—the exact details describing how it will be executed. In order to perfect it, we need time, a team of talented industry professionals, and funding. And since the project needs to be picked up before a network will fund it, we are asking for your help.

Over the next month or so, Frank and I will be dedicated to this project. Our plan is to present it to the network executives this spring. I know we will receive a “yes” after they view this detailed plan, read the scripts and see just how passionate fans are about making this film series a reality. There isn’t any other answer except “yes”. So let’s make this happen! After all, you’re the reason I’m being given this opportunity. You allowed Emma’s story into your lives. And I am so grateful to you for trusting me with your hearts. Now I ask that you trust me once again, and you will see Emma’s story come to life.

View Franks Video Here.

Your Choice

$10 -Thank You Tweet

  • A personalized Thank You Tweet from Rebecca Donovan!

 

 

 

 

 

 

$15 - Digital Autograph

  • An Autographed Digital Cover of Reason to Breathe (The Original Cover!)
  • A Thank you Tweet from Rebecca Donovan

$25 - Put It In Writing

  • Limited Edition Breathing Trilogy Movie Pen
  • “Keep Calm and Kiss Evan” Breathing Trilogy Movie Sticker
  • Autographed Digital Cover of Reason to Breathe (The Original Cover!)
  • Thank you Tweet from Rebecca Donovan

$50 - Wear It

  • Limited Edition Breathing Trilogy Film Series T-Shirt
  • Limited Edition Breathing Trilogy Film Series Pen
  • “Keep Calm and Kiss Evan” Breathing Trilogy Movie Sticker

$100 - What They Said

  • An Autographed Copy of the First Episode's Script
  • The Breathing Trilogy Film Series T-Shirt
  • Limited Edition Breathing Trilogy Film Series Pen
  • “Keep Calm and Kiss Evan” Breathing Trilogy Film Series Sticker

$500 - I Unpacked for You

  • An “Unpacked Box” filled with Rebecca’s Handpicked Favorite Things
  • Limited Edition Breathing Trilogy Film Series Pen
  • “Keep Calm and Kiss Evan” Breathing Trilogy Film Series Sticker

$2,500 - A Brand New Story (Limit 2 Individuals)

  • Be a beta reader for Rebecca’s next novel! (Read it before it’s available for sale!)
  • “Unpacked Box” filled with Rebecca’s Handpicked Favorite Things
  • Autographed Copy of the First Episode's Script
  • The Breathing Trilogy Film Series T-Shirt
  • Limited Edition Breathing Trilogy Film Series Pen
  • “Keep Calm and Kiss Evan” Breathing Trilogy Film Series Sticker
  • Autographed Digital Cover of Reason to Breathe (The Original Cover!)
  • Thank you Tweet from Rebecca Donovan

Be our voice in the crowd - spread the word! 

Shout it from the rooftops. Okay, maybe not literally - we'd hate for you to fall.

Share the campaign on social media: Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, you name it! 

Encourage others to read the series.  Let the world know how passionate you are about this project! Your voice will be heard!

story:
A SARI FOR PALLAVI is Sunita Deshpande's first play. Out of 1500 entries, it was chosen as a top 10 nominee at the Samuel French OOB Festival this year.

Straight-forward with heart, A SARI FOR PALLAVI is about two dueling cousins - Traditional Thini & Promiscuous Pallavi - as they decide what to wear to an upcoming wedding. (Hint: Pallavi does NOT want to wear a sari, but rather something much slinkier.)

Sunita took a Labyrinth Theatre workshop in January 2013 where A SARI FOR PALLAVI was born. Her teacher and class encouraged her to keep writing and enter contests.

After the Samuel French OOB Festival, a friend and director/producer, Kate Chamuris, wanted to help bring this story to a wider audience and adapt it into a short film. In the film adaptation, Sunita will be playing both parts, reflecting where this play came from in the first place: the dueling identities within all of us. The traditional v. the modern.

Now we’re making that play into a film!

 

Hi I’m Sunita Deshpande, I’m a writer, actor, and improviser living in NYC. I want to tell you why I have heart for this project.

Growing up in a small city outside of Tampa, Florida - I didn’t really know many Indian kids like me. Some are born to be doctors and scientists. I was born to pick up my dad’s clunky video camera (eye-piece held in with Scotch tape)  and make my sister be in comedy videos with me.

Look - before you start to feel bad for Rina - she’s the lucky one here! She added Gaffer, PA, Best boy, and Extra to her resume like that. I was her first internship. You are welcome, Rina.

Watching my parents belly-laugh at the videos after a hard day was my favorite lesson in how comedy can heal.

 

Hi, I'm Kate Chamuris a director and producer.

I made the transition from in front of the camera to behind the camera a few years ago when I started telling my own stories. Sunita and I met about ten years ago performing improv around New York City. Recently, I had the opportunity to direct her in the series I co-created called BREAKFAST IN BED.

Over a catch-up tea about a year ago, Sunita was telling me about the enthusiasm and support already accumulating around A SARI FOR PALLAVI. Upon reading her script, I immediately connected to the universal conflict of when family and society dictate what we should be doing with our lives and what we truthfully want for ourselves. I'm often in that headspace and I know many of you feel the same.

 

PALLAVI is a 26 year-old Indian-American girl who goes against the grain in every way. Born and raised in LA, she works in social media and loves to party. She can’t wait to wear something skimpy (hint: not a sari) to her cousin’s upcoming wedding to make her ex-boyfriend jealous.

 

THINI is a 27 year-old, orthodox, Bangalorean-raised Indian woman who moved to LA a month ago. Studying to be a doctor, she believes in honoring family and tradition, and will do anything to make Shruti Auntie happy - including make Pallavi wear a sari to their cousin’s upcoming wedding.

 

Of course, we’re going to need money to pull this project off. There will be makeup needs, costume needs, lighting, food for the crew, the crew to feed, and of course editing Sunita & Sunita together. Whatever we raise through your generous donations will be dispersed in the following categories.

 

We’ve got some amazing packages and goodies for our donors - including mugs that Sunita's sister (Rina Deshpande) has designed as well as custom tote bags, digital downloads of the movie, social media shout-outs, and more.

 

The best part of all of this is you will be contributing to a female writer-director team and a showcasing the next generation of dramedy storytelling. You’ll be participating in new and diverse stories being told all over the world.

Other ways you can help are putting the word out about us on social media by sharing our campaign link ( https://igg.me/at/a-sari-for-pallavi ) and of course, watching and sharing the finished movie with your friends.

The biggest thing we've learned from adapting this play into a film script is, the more specific one writes the more universal the audience becomes. Truly we are all connected, despite stories being so vast and different, and that is an amazing thing.

So donate to A SARI FOR PALLAVI today. Look, it has to be a good script, Samuel French can’t be wrong. We guarantee it will bring heartfelt belly-laughs.

 

Best, thank you, and love to you all -

A Sari for Pallavi - short film TEAM
